title: [flutter_tools] Add ARM64 Linux host and cross-building option support
author: Hidenori Matsubayashi

comments.author: fluttergithubbot
comments.bodyText:
It looks like this pull request may not have tests. Please make sure to add tests before merging. If you need an exemption to this rule, contact Hixie on the #hackers channel in Chat.
Reviewers: Read the Tree Hygiene page and make sure this patch meets those guidelines before LGTMing.

comments.author: christopherfujino
comments.bodyText: @HidenoriMatsubayashi did you actually build the binaries and get this working, or is this a proof of concept? When I said I could help you with infra, I misunderstood and thought you had a working linux arm host setup. I can point you in the right direction, but I don't really have bandwidth to work on this at the moment.

comments.author: HidenoriMatsubayashi
comments.bodyText:
@christopherfujino

did you actually build the binaries and get this working, or is this a proof of concept?

Yes, I did. I use my customized sysrootfs for aarch64, but here is a binary for sample flutter app built with Flutter SDK with this patch. Works with ARM64 platforms such as JetsonNao. Of course, I also use a locally built version of Flutter Engine.
https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/flutter-examples/blob/master/flutter_aarch64_sample.zip


I misunderstood and thought you had a working linux arm host setup.

I see. No problem at all.
By the way, I've also tried it partially. I did dart-sdk cross build for aarch64.

comments.author: christopherfujino
comments.bodyText:
@HidenoriMatsubayashi That's awesome to hear!
Did you cross-build Dart directly from the https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk repo, or via Flutter's engine environment? I was able to do the former, but got stuck on the latter before I had to move on to other things.

comments.author: HidenoriMatsubayashi
comments.bodyText:
@christopherfujino

Did you cross-build Dart directly from the https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk repo, or via Flutter's engine environment?

A while ago, I tried to cross-build Dart directly from the https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk repo for running Flutter SDK (flutter commands) on ARM64 Host. I basically tried the steps here.  I think the build result worked on Raspberry Pi 4.
(By the way, I use Flutter Engine environment for building Flutter Engine (so files etc.).)

I was able to do the former, but got stuck on the latter before I had to move on to other things.

What exactly was the problem? If you want to support running flutter sdk on ARM64 Host, I may be able to help you..

comments.author: nhjk
comments.bodyText: Any updates on this?

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText:
Addressing some of the questions/comments in the initial description:

Should the result of the x86_64 and aarch64 builds be in separate directories?

Yes, definitely (unless there's a fat/universal build option for Linux that I'm not aware of). We should not stomp builds with different target outputs.

Should we include aarch64 rootfs in the Flutter SDK?

This seems out of scope for Flutter; we don't ship and use a sysroot for the current builds.

We will need infra updates so that you can download artifacts (Flutter Eingine build results, etc.) to the following locations.

This would be the first place to start, IMO. We also need confirmation/commitment from Dart folks that cross-compile tooling (e.g., for gen_snapshot) is a supported configuration on Linux.

comments.author: HidenoriMatsubayashi
comments.bodyText:
@nikiask
I'm a bit busy. But I'm still working.
@stuartmorgan
Thank you for your reply.
@christopherfujino
FYI. Here is the procedure for cross-build and running dart-sdk I tried. Basically cross-build procedure is as per the official wiki.

Build dart-sdk on Host PC (Ubuntu x64)

$ mkdir dart-sdk
$ cd dart-sdk
$ git clone https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/tools/depot_tools.git
$ export PATH="$PATH:$PWD/depot_tools"
$ fetch dart
$ cd dart
$ ./tools/build.py --no-goma -m release -a arm64
$ cd out/ReleaseXARM64/
$ tar zcf /tmp/dart-sdk.tar.gz dart-sdk


run Flutte SDK on Jetson Nano (Ubuntu arm64)

$ git clone https://github.com/flutter/flutter.git
$ export PATH=$PATH:./flutter/bin
$ tar xf dart-sdk.tar.gz

Replace dart-sdk after the error.
$ flutter doctor
  build error!!

$ rm -rf flutter/bin/cache/dart-sdk
$ cp -rf dart-sdk flutter/bin/cache

$ flutter doctor

comments.author: christopherfujino
HidenoriMatsubayashi
comments.bodyText:
@christopherfujino

I'm guessing I need to provide a sysroot?

Yes. There are two ways. One is to use an external sysroot. Another way is to modify buildroot to use debian_sid_arm64-sysroot. I have tried both, and built Flutter Engine.
I could cross-build and pass the build.. I am going to send the PR.
https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/engine/tree/topic-support-linux-aarch64-cross-build
https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/buildroot/tree/topic-support-linux-aarch64-cross-build
.gclient file that I used is following.
solutions = [
  {
    "managed": False,
    "name": "src/flutter",
    "url": "https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/engine.git@9158ef84c326dc7260bfe39dd65189dd033d0b29",
    "custom_deps": {},
    "deps_file": "DEPS",
    "safesync_url": "",
  },
]

You need to modify flutter/DEPS file by yourself.
  'src': 'https://github.com/flutter/buildroot.git' + '@' + 'fe3b46e595e7ce1350e11aa0c90365976051f4a3',
↓
  'src': 'https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/buildroot.git' + '@' + '5658a5f9168a0025d25eb700b607abc4b1e247af',

Build Flutter Engine. The build is successful. But it is necessary to be careful about version combinations when actually run a Flutter app because of version check of DartVM.
$ ./flutter/tools/gn --target-os linux --linux-cpu arm64 --runtime-mode release
$ ninja -C out/linux_release_arm64

$ ./flutter/tools/gn --target-os linux --linux-cpu arm64 --runtime-mode debug
$ ninja -C out/linux_debug_arm64

comments.author: HidenoriMatsubayashi
comments.bodyText:
I confirmed that the dart-sdk built above works on ARM64 Host. However, the flutter app has not been executed yet due to the error of dart-sdk. I am currently investigating..

comments.bodyText:
@christopherfujino

I'm guessing I need to provide a sysroot?

Yes. There are two ways. One is to use an external sysroot. Another way is to modify buildroot to use debian_sid_arm64-sysroot. I have tried both, and built Flutter Engine.
I could cross-build and pass the build.. I am going to send the PR.
https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/engine/tree/topic-support-linux-aarch64-cross-build
https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/buildroot/tree/topic-support-linux-aarch64-cross-build
.gclient file that I used is following.
solutions = [
  {
    "managed": False,
    "name": "src/flutter",
    "url": "https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/engine.git@9158ef84c326dc7260bfe39dd65189dd033d0b29",
    "custom_deps": {},
    "deps_file": "DEPS",
    "safesync_url": "",
  },
]

You need to modify flutter/DEPS file by yourself.
  'src': 'https://github.com/flutter/buildroot.git' + '@' + 'fe3b46e595e7ce1350e11aa0c90365976051f4a3',
↓
  'src': 'https://github.com/HidenoriMatsubayashi/buildroot.git' + '@' + '5658a5f9168a0025d25eb700b607abc4b1e247af',

Build Flutter Engine. The build is successful. But it is necessary to be careful about version combinations when actually run a Flutter app because of version check of DartVM.
$ ./flutter/tools/gn --target-os linux --linux-cpu arm64 --runtime-mode release
$ ninja -C out/linux_release_arm64

$ ./flutter/tools/gn --target-os linux --linux-cpu arm64 --runtime-mode debug
$ ninja -C out/linux_debug_arm64


This is great! When I get some free time I'll check this out.

Thank you for your reply.
@christopherfujino
FYI. Here is the procedure for cross-build and running dart-sdk I tried. Basically cross-build procedure is as per the official wiki.

Build dart-sdk on Host PC (Ubuntu x64)

$ mkdir dart-sdk
$ cd dart-sdk
$ git clone https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/tools/depot_tools.git
$ export PATH="$PATH:$PWD/depot_tools"
$ fetch dart
$ cd dart
$ ./tools/build.py --no-goma -m release -a arm64
$ cd out/ReleaseXARM64/
$ tar zcf /tmp/dart-sdk.tar.gz dart-sdk


run Flutte SDK on Jetson Nano (Ubuntu arm64)

$ git clone https://github.com/flutter/flutter.git
$ export PATH=$PATH:./flutter/bin
$ tar xf dart-sdk.tar.gz

Replace dart-sdk after the error.
$ flutter doctor
  build error!!

$ rm -rf flutter/bin/cache/dart-sdk
$ cp -rf dart-sdk flutter/bin/cache

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText:
I think there are enough questions as to what this should look like exactly for the developer, and enough points that will be in common with other platforms (e.g., eventual Windows arm64 support) that we should really have a design doc for the tooling plan before moving forward with a PR. It would need to answer questions like what the targets should be called and what they mean, e.g.:

Is linux still a build option (vs linux-x64 and linux-arm64 or similar)? If so, does it mean "same as host" or "x64"?
How should the build output be structured for multi-arch output?
For Linux, how is the sysroot handled?

comments.author: HidenoriMatsubayashi
comments.bodyText:
@stuartmorgan
Thank you for your comment and advice.

we should really have a design doc for the tooling plan before moving forward with a PR

I agree with you. Is it enough to add my idea to the description so that we can discuss? Or is there any other way?

Is linux still a build option (vs linux-x64 and linux-arm64 or similar)? If so, does it mean "same as host" or "x64"?

No, it isn't. I'm sorry for confusing you. I updated the description. Now, I want to run the Flutter SDK on an arm64 host.

How should the build output be structured for multi-arch output?

At the time of self-build, the build output will be output to build/linux/. It's the same as the current output directory structure. On the other hand, at the time of cross-build, it will be output to build/linux-cross/.
How about my idea?

For Linux, how is the sysroot handled?

I have considered that an user can specify a sysroot prepared by themselves in the build option. I think it would be better to have an option for them to freely specify sysroot. Because Flutter Engine has similar options.
$ flutter build linux --target-platform=linux-arm64 --target-sysroot=/target-sysroot-path

But If the Flutter SDK download the sysroot used to cross-build the Flutter Engine first, they don't need to prepare anything.

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText:
Is it enough to add my idea to the description so that we can discuss? Or is there any other way?

https://flutter.dev/docs/resources/design-docs


Is linux still a build option (vs linux-x64 and linux-arm64 or similar)? If so, does it mean "same as host" or "x64"?

No, it isn't. I'm sorry for confusing you. I updated the description. Now, I want to run the Flutter SDK on an arm64 host.

How should the build output be structured for multi-arch output?

At the time of self-build, the build output will be output to build/linux/. It's the same as the current output directory structure. On the other hand, at the time of cross-build, it will be output to build/linux-cross/.

Sorry, I wasn't clear. These weren't questions about how your patch works, these are questions that all stakeholders need to agree on what we want the solutions to be, not only for Linux, but for other platforms where we need this in the future such as Windows. (E.g., I'm not at all sold on having two different build directories whose contents depend on the host machine, vs., say, always doing linux/x64/... and linux/arm64/...)
And a design document is the best place to have a discussion like that.

Note: The sluggishness on my rk3399 devices with Flutter web is most likely because of the GPU driver and how it works with Chromium itself, not because of Flutter.

The cause is that  dart-sdk-linux-arm64.zip does not contain the files under the dev_compiler directory. In addition, the dart-sdk for Linux arm64 in Dart SDK archive also does not contain these files. On the other hand, dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip contains these files.
It seems to be included only for x64 architectures and I think this is a dart-sdk issue. dart-lang/sdk#39312
For the moment, I copied the files contained in dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip to the local cache and I confirmed that a sample app works onRaspberry Pi4.

comments.author: christopherfujino

'/home/hidenori/workspace/flutter/bin/cache/dart-sdk/lib/dev_compiler/kernel/amd/require.js' (OS Error:
No such file or directory, errno = 2)".

Detailed log
The cause is that dart-sdk-linux-arm64.zip does not contain the files under the dev_compiler directory. In addition, the dart-sdk for Linux arm64 in Dart SDK archive also does not contain these files. On the other hand, dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip contains these files.
It seems to be included only for x64 architectures and I think this is a dart-sdk issue. dart-lang/sdk#39312
For the moment, I copied the files contained in dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip to the local cache and I confirmed that a sample app works onRaspberry Pi4.

Thanks for investigating. We'll have to either upstream the fix, or apply a hack in the tool...
For posterity, this is the tracking issue dart-lang/sdk#43776

comments.author: saurik
comments.bodyText:
Getting web working on arm64 linux seems like a nice-to-have for now.

FWIW, just to provide some feedback on interest: I have been eagerly tracking this issue all week specifically because I want to be doing Flutter Web builds on ARM. I have been wanting to use cheaper ARM servers for deployment of my web sites and use cheaper ARM machines for my parallel CI on deployment and build, and even have a specific driving use case this week building a web interface on some ARM routers--on which I have been hoping to build the code in addition to just deploy it, as they have more than enough RAM, and I imagine a lot of my downstream users will find this to be the easiest way to prove the binary reproduction--and I couldn't honestly care less about native app stuff working on Linux ARM hosts as it isn't like I really ever see ARM machines locally / in real life that are running Linux (so discounting the Surface or an new Apple MacBook) except for the occasional Raspberry Pi attached to a monitor temporarily.
Regardless, I am definitely excited to see progress is at least being made on this front!

FYI. Here is the procedure for cross-build and running dart-sdk I tried. Basically cross-build procedure is as per the official wiki.

Build dart-sdk on Host PC (Ubuntu x64)

$ mkdir dart-sdk
$ cd dart-sdk
$ git clone https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/tools/depot_tools.git
$ export PATH="$PATH:$PWD/depot_tools"
$ fetch dart
$ cd dart
$ ./tools/build.py --no-goma -m release -a arm64
$ cd out/ReleaseXARM64/
$ tar zcf /tmp/dart-sdk.tar.gz dart-sdk


run Flutte SDK on Jetson Nano (Ubuntu arm64)

$ git clone https://github.com/flutter/flutter.git
$ export PATH=$PATH:./flutter/bin
$ tar xf dart-sdk.tar.gz

Building the artifacts for a new platform is a substantial effort. The cost for doing so should be discussed in a new issue and not done as a part of this PR.
What workflows do these changes break? We don't currently support 32bit arm as either a host or target platform on Linux, but if something was working by accident before that would be great to know.

comments.author: psstoyanov
comments.bodyText:
Can we use this on android arm64?
I can install dart on android + termux,
but flutter doesn't support android host, and no prebuilt tools for android arm64.

Using Termux or similar approach may be possible (as long as the app provides aarch64 userland and you have enough RAM - both will be impacted by how Android operates).
Android build tools aren't available for aarch64 afaik. Pretty much the mention of Android Studio not supporting arm64 in the design document (note that IntelliJ IDEs are using Java and can run on arm devices however the android build tools to create the apps aren't available for that platform).
Android host doesn't seem likely but that has a lot more to do with the OS itself. Your best bet would be Termux or similar (results will be of questionable success).
This PR is addressing Linux aarch64 host support. If you get Linux aarch64 environment on Android - sure. Otherwise, the PR is not relevant to your use case

title: `OverlayPortal`
author: LongCatIsLooong

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: Also on a different note, @rrousselGit @fzyzcjy how would like to receive the due credit? I can add a code comment before the OverlayPortal class and say "this is Inspired by the flutter_portal package"? If that works for you, do you want your github handles added to the comment as well?

comments.author: rrousselGit
comments.bodyText:
"this is Inspired by the flutter_portal package"? If that works for you, do you want your github handles added to the comment as well?

That's fine by me :)

comments.author: fzyzcjy
comments.bodyText:
"this is Inspired by the flutter_portal package"? If that works for you, do you want your github handles added to the comment as well?

Also fine for me :)

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
This seems almost guaranteed to cause some unexpected interaction, but I admit I cannot think what it might be...
We should have tests for at least all of the following:

GlobalKey reparenting between a regular overlay entry and a portal entry, both forwards and backwards, and in both orders (i.e. four tests).
GlobalKey reparenting between a two portal entries, both forwards and backwards, and in both orders.
GlobalKey reparenting between a portal entry and the regular child of the surrogate, in both directions and both orders.
Something that only causes the portal to rebuild, the portal child to rebuild, the proxy to rebuild, the proxy's regular child to rebuild.
Every test again, but with a layout builder between the overlay and the proxy.
Nested overlays with nested portals (overlays inside portals, inside proxies, etc).

comments.author: nilsreichardt
comments.bodyText: cc: @creativecreatorormaybenot

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: Started working on adding more test, @Hixie by proxy you mean the PortalOverlay widget right?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Started working on adding more test, @Hixie by proxy you mean the PortalOverlay widget right?

I meant the addDeferredChild API, but I guess that's the same thing since it's private.
(It'd be interesting to see if there was a way to implement this so that Overlay and _Theatre itself was agnostic about all this, so that other people could create their own interesting variants.)

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
(It'd be interesting to see if there was a way to implement this so that Overlay and _Theatre itself was agnostic about all this, so that other people could create their own interesting variants.)

Something like #39104? The addDeferredChild thing is only safe on a render parent whose children are independently sized, and independently positioned, in case it's called inside of a LayoutBuilder, so it can adopt render children during layout and finish everything in one frame. So I guess the only thing that qualifies is an Overlay/_RenderTheatre?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: @LongCatIsLooong I tried checking this out to play with it but it had a lot of conflicts (and many commits so it was hard to figure out how to resolve them) -- any chance you could merge this to tip of tree?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
I found a problem with this approach. It breaks the invariant that Material relies on, namely that if it can find a Material.of during build, that guarantees that it can find the corresponding Material widget's render object during paint.
You can reproduce this problem by putting an InkWell inside an OverlayPortal's overlayChild and then tapping it.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: Another issue I ran into is that the logic that toggles the presence of the DebugBanner when you take a screenshot from the command line (hit s in the flutter run console) causes the whole thing to fall over (screen goes red with an assertion error deep in the framework) so long as you have a portal active.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: I suspect it's the same as the DebugBanner issue, but for what it's worth, selecting "Select Widget Mode" in the devtools also causes the framework to throw an assertion that turns the screen red.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
Regarding material, I made some changes to how material computes the paint transform to each InkFeature so it stops throwing (but if the InkFeature extends outside of the material it'll still get clipped to materials bounding rect). But since this pull request doesn't actually break anything by itself, should I move the fix and the test to another PR?
Also I messed up something in activate and deactivate, now taking screenshots should be working.

comments.author: goderbauer
goderbauer
Hixie
Hixie
comments.bodyText: The test in #105335 (comment) is actually really good at showing this bug. Double tap each button, and the corresponding container just moves to the top of the rendering, even though the tree order hasn't changed.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
I initially thought I could just put addChild in an invokeLayoutCallback to workaround the _debugCanPerformMutations assert but that didn't work.
@Hixie yeah I'm planning to add that as a separate feature. Shouldn't be very difficult to implement the correct paint order once we figured out the right API for that I think (see PR description).

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
I think if we want to use this with Overlay then getting the z-index right is actually pretty critical. There's no way to know when a random widget one uses happens to use LayoutBuilder, and that would mean developers could not get predictable results.
I can imagine a world where we use this for multiwindow rather than Overlay and in that world the z-index issue wouldn't matter much (since the windowing system is then in charge of z-index issues).

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: Looking at the OverlayEntry usages in the framework that could potentially be ported to OverlayPortal, most of them are just some sort of prompts that show at the top of the theatre, and go away/yield once the user interacts with something else so  I feel the current "chronological" paint order works well enough as the default. @Hixie would you be ok with only exposing the default constructor that just paints children in the order they were added for now? I'm not super confident that I'll be able to come up with something in a vacuum that addresses the paint order problem and covers all use cases.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
do you think the following API would be expressive enough for specifying the z-index/paint order?

What happens if two OverlayPortals that get inserted in the same frame specify the same after location?

Looking at the OverlayEntry usages in the framework that could potentially be ported to OverlayPortal, most of them are just some sort of prompts that show at the top of the theatre

For these, proper z-ordering probably doesn't matter as much as long as you only put up one OverlayPortal per frame. But I am not sure if we can guarantee that? What is somebody starts building a Navigator implementation where all the routes are OverlayPortals? In that world you could potentially put more then one route on the stack per frame and you need to guarantee ordering somehow. OverlayPortals could in the future also be used to animate multiple parts of a UI to a new position when e.g. the window size changes. Here, z ordering between the elements as they are in motion could also matter... Solving this (or having a plan for it) could enable some interesting use cases in the future.
I am actually also still concerned about keeping the order stable when you move an OverlayPortal via a GlobalKey. Here, it will be very visible when Overlays suddenly start changing their z order somewhat unpredictably. And GlobalKey moves are not that uncommon...

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: One thing that came up in in-person discussion: How do you use this system to place an OverlayPortal into the root overlay? We do this in the framework in a couple of places where things should be placed in the largest Overlay available to avoid that they get cut off by the bounds of sub overlays.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
It's hard for me to evaluate the OverlayLocation API because I don't really know what the use case is for me to use it.
My concern with z-index ordering is around the default behaviour, e.g. the way that having different ancestors (LayoutBuilder or not, for example, or SliverList or not) changes the z-index. For example, if you have something in a SliverList that shows an overlay, then something in a LayoutBuilder that shows one, the second will be above the first, but then if you scroll the list so that the item is dropped then scroll back so it comes back, suddenly the one in the list is on top... this seems fundamentally wrong to me, because as a developer it is unpredictable.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: (BTW, I don't want to make all my comments sound negative. I find this PR to be astoundingly clever and much, much more reliable than one might expect from something that messes with the tree in this way. Even if we never land it, it's an achievement and shows a really solid understanding of the internals of our trees and my hat is off to you.)

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
Here's another actual use case where overlay order would likely matter: #50763
Also +1 to what Hixie said about the cleverness of this PR. When I first read it I was amazed by how this uses depth manipulation to achieve its goal. And when I tried it out, I was surprised (in a good way) how robust the mechanism is.

comments.author: HansMuller
comments.bodyText: @goderbauer - I don't think that #50763 could be resolved by OverlayPortal, even given tight control over z-indices.  To avoid the flash that occurs when the Hero moves from the overlay to it's final location, you'd need to snake it through the non-overlay UI at the right overall z-index. That doesn't seem possible, since each Renderer defines the stacking order of it's children (and only its children).

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: I was describing this problem to someone just now and it struck me that one way we could turn the weakness of this PR (the z-index looking like it should be predictable based on tree order but where it is actually based on insertion order) into a strength would be to actually use something similar to the current Overlay API: make adding the portal child imperative. Maybe have a controller, or have the State be how you trigger the child being visible? Not as clean an API, but more predictable...

comments.author: fzyzcjy
comments.bodyText:
the z-index looking like it should be predictable based on tree order but where it is actually based on insertion order

Can we add a zIndex argument in the portals, and allow the user to explicitly provide it, just like what they did with web technology. Then, we can use something like a TreeMap<int, OurObject> (where key is z-index and value is the object we are interested) to replace List<OurObject> to obtain "render by z-index" easily.
Btw, one of the core improvements of portal is its declarativeness, thus IMHO making it declarative will be quite helpful for the users.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: The way z-index works in CSS is a constant source of problems (with people one-upping themselves with bigger and bigger numbers to be "on top"). We should definitely not use the CSS style. (Also it doesn't solve this problem because you still have to determine how to disambiguate identical values.)

comments.author: Hixie
fzyzcjy
comments.bodyText:
That sounds interesting, but I am a bit confused:
If ZIndex is implemented completely by the user (not flutter), then we rely on user to do the tricky below/above. This is very error-proone, because users may accidentially provide, e.g., circular or wrong below/above. We may add assert checks to runtime check it, but the risk still exists in release build (and no check at all).
If it is implemented in Flutter (since it is not an abstract class), not sure how users should use it. If users are going to maintain a linked list by themselves, maybe we can provide a ZIndexLinkedList directly for them, then even no need for above/below but we can directly utilize the order in the ZIndexLinkedList.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
The ZIndex class seems to be pretty close to the other OverlayLocation interface I have right now. But what are the benefits of requiring a total order < on ZIndex? It doesn't seem to make the order more predictable, as above() or below() will be typically called in build so it still reflects the build order?
The other inconvenience ZIndex and OverlayLocation both have is that they both are relative and in some cases it's difficult to get the base ZIndex from the widget tree, as in theory it could be created by a descendant widget

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
@fzyzcjy

If it is implemented in Flutter (since it is not an abstract class), not sure how users should use it.

They would have to set up a ZIndex instance ahead of time (e.g. in initState), for example by calling ZIndex.top.above(), and then pass it to the OverlayPortal.
@LongCatIsLooong

The only complain I have for this would be overlayChild has to be non-null in the next build after a show call, and the developer has to call setState explicitly.

Yeah. We could require overlayChild to always be non-null, that would solve those two issues. There's other problems, like you can't put anything in the overlay in the same frame as you get created (but maybe that's true anyway? I guess it must be since the overlay has to finish building before we get to build?).

But what are the benefits of requiring a total order < on ZIndex?

Well the key is that it's impossible to have two OverlayPortals with an ambiguous position. Since no two portals can be given the same key, and all keys are different, it's always unambiguous what order they go in.

as above() or below() will be typically called in build so it still reflects the build order?

Certainly the API can be misused, yes. Doing that would be akin to creating a Future in the build method for an AsyncBuilder, which is not uncommon. We could try to lint our way out of it but I agree that it's not ideal.
I agree that the controller idea is probably better.

The other inconvenience ZIndex and OverlayLocation both have is that they both are relative and in some cases it's difficult to get the base ZIndex from the widget tree, as in theory it could be created by a descendant widget

I don't really follow. Can you elaborate?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Here's what a ZIndex implementation could look like: zindex.zip
I do agree the controller idea is less bug-prone though.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
Nevermind I got a bit too excited about the controller approach, it won't allow OverlayPortal to target the root Overlay because the initial root Overlay may have a shorter lifespan than the OverlayPortal.

you can't put anything in the overlay in the same frame as you get created (but maybe that's true anyway? I guess it must be since the overlay has to finish building before we get to build?).

Not the best practice but I'd expect show hide to be safe to call in the build method that builds the OverlayPortal. The implementation of show basically just grabs the current timestamp for sorting during paint, and hide tells the Element to treat overlayChild as null. It's still built on top of the declarative API.
As an example of the inconvenience, say I want to build a generic Magnifier widget that places a magnifier at a desired z-index. Then that widget would have to pass down a box to get the Z-index from its descendant (in the case of a text field, there're times the magnifier should be put under/above the selection handle).

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
fzyzcjy
comments.bodyText: Looks like the "This API is inspired by ..." comment disappears (searched through overlay.dart) 👀 Or do I miss something

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
Looks like the "This API is inspired by ..." comment disappears (searched through overlay.dart) eyes Or do I miss something

Added that as a code comment

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: Overall this is looking pretty good. I wonder if we can reduce the complexity in _OverlayEntryLocation and _RenderTheatreChildModel a little bit by removing some of the abstractions that are currently unused. Also, instead of introducing this new childIterator paradigm, could _RenderTheatreChildModel use one of the existing paradims (e.g. visitChildren or exposing firstChild/lastChild with a field to get to the next/previous one) to avoid introducing a new concept?

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: visitChildren traversal is not lazy I think. You'll have to go through the entire child list so it's not optimal for hit testing.

comments.author: AlexV525
comments.bodyText: 👀 Still actively working on it? @LongCatIsLooong

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: This is ready for another round of review

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: TODO: @gspencergoog pointed out Scrollable.ensureVisible may throw because Scrollable.of uses the Element tree to find the closest render viewport.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
remove some of the additional layers of abstraction that the implementation doesn't appear to take advantage of, but make following the code harder

removed the child model abstract class. As for the OverlayLocation class I'd like to keep that for now since I'm planning to make that public in the future.

sticking to Flutter's more traditional models of iterating over children instead of inventing a new iterator model

Switched to using Iterable & generator functions, hopefully the latter isn't banned?

clearer ownership of pieces of data (e.g. the "timestamp")

The OverlayLocation owns the timestamp. But I don't want to create OverlayLocations early so other things will have to hold them

clearer API boundaries (e.g. the child model feels like an implementation detail of the OverlayEntry (or the RenderTheater?) but it appears to be passed around everywhere

I think we want the child model to reflect the z-index and to make the z-index somewhat customizable the overlay location needs to have access to the target child model. But in the future I think it will mostly be the OverlayLocation that's getting passed around.

some terminology clean-up (e.g. timestamp)

any suggestions? alternatively I could do a typedef _Time = int and make timestamp a _Time?

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
TODO: @gspencergoog pointed out Scrollable.ensureVisible may throw because Scrollable.of uses the Element tree to find the closest render viewport.

Is there maybe a general problem that certain inherited widgets should not propagate to the portaled widget? I think I am running into the same problem with the multi view design. While some inherited widgets should be available (think themes and data models) others are more questionable, like Scrollable.of or Navigator.of. I wonder if we need to design something to tag certain inherited widgets as "these don't travel across view/portal boundaries".

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: MediaQuery is another interesting case. Technically, I think the portaled widget should see the MediaQuery of the location they were portaled to, not the one from the location they were portaled from. (I was just thinking about this for the mutli view case.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
wrt InheritedWidgets, I think for the most part it's just some inherit widgets making assumptions that may no longer be true so that should be fixed from the InheritedWidget side?


Scrollable:
Are there places where Scrollable.ensureVisible should be used over RenderObject.showOnScreen? The former seems to make more assumptions and may break when "widget a is an ancestor of widget b" doesn't imply "renderObject a is an ancestor of renderObject b".


MediaQuery
The MediaQueryData class provides information about the surface (e.g. paddings and insets), and on the other hand it has some other things like textScaleFactor that it should probably inherit from its owner's widget tree. OverlayPortal probably should have its own MediaQuery.


I'm not sure how Navigator.of can be problematic. Calling Navigator.of in the overlay child should give you it's owner's (the one that created the overlay portal) NavigatorState?

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
If the OverlayLocation needs to be created anyways, what's the harm in creating it right away?

That way you can create multiple locations in the same frame, none of them will be used except for the last one. OverlayLocation is used as Slot and has a lifecycle, so I think it's easier to reason about if we only create when needed.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
From a discussion with @LongCatIsLooong
For Views I have come to the conclusion that we need inheritance boundaries. There are certain widgets that should not flow into the View. One example is the Material widget. If you use a button in a subview, it should not see the Material widget in the main view because it doesn't make sense to draw the sparkles of the subview button into the main view. Instead, it should require that there is a Material widget in the subview itself.
I think it is the same for portals.
Also, we should make sure that OverlayPortals are a drop-in replacement for Views. Basically, OverlayPortals simulate sub-windows. We should probably hold off on this until the View stuff is a little further along. Fitting in Overlay Boundaries retro-actively doesn't sound like a good idea.

Maybe something like an extended UML diagram. That diagram could help with identifying potential simplifications and also document how the entire implementation works.

title: Proposal: A more complete app template for Flutter
author: Brian Egan

comments.author: filiph
comments.bodyText:
Hi @Hixie, would you please have a look at this PR, and/or suggest other reviewers?
This is the project that adds a more complete template (flutter create -t full, go/flutter-more-complete-template). Issue at #76379.
We have a 24-page public document explaining all the micro-decisions that went into this. I recommend skimming through it since it may pre-empt some understandable questions and raised eyebrows.

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText:
Sorry if this is in the linked docs, but what is the plan for testing this?
Relatedly, I'm wondering if this could be an opportunity for demonstrating testing practices by including a few more non-trivial tests in the template itself.

comments.author: filiph
comments.bodyText:
Sorry if this is in the linked docs, but what is the plan for testing this?

Is there a test for the current flutter create template (the "counter app") that we could look at for inspiration?

Relatedly, I'm wondering if this could be an opportunity for demonstrating testing practices by including a few more non-trivial tests in the template itself.

Here's our thinking on this. In short: we see that, with the current template, developers introduce breaking changes to the template in the first 5 minutes of their work, and then the smoke test is broken (often statically broken, so there are analyzer errors and squiggly lines). The effect is that the (otherwise very educational!) test/widget_test.dart file gets deleted or commented out. For that reason, the approach is to have relatively trivial tests that can't be broken (they don't depend on lib/) but that still provide some boilerplate (test('...', () {})) and links to documentation.
Nothing here is set in stone, though.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: We need to find a way to not duplicate the existing platform files. We occasionally have to update these, and having 2 copies of everything is going to increase the chances that we accidentally get out of sync somewhere.

comments.author: brianegan
comments.bodyText:
Thanks again for the review, everyone. I've gone through and updated the tool a bit to support the new template. Features include:

Updated template based on feedback.

Remove analysis_options
Fix comments
Route restoration
Full types for all closures
use relative imports


Shared Platform Files. To share files, I've introduced the concept of a "merged" template, which combines several source templates & their template_images into a single destination.

templates/app_shared  - Contains all files shared between different apps
templates/app - only files needed by counter app
templates/list_detail_app - only files needed by the new template.
Submitted PR to flutter_template_images to ensure the directory structure is in sync


Added tests

We've decided NOT to include any implementation tests in the final template, but we want to test the app before we ship it.
To support this Use Case, I've added an implentation-tests flag to the flutter create command. If this flag is set to true, the template will render .test.tmpl files found in the source directories and copy .golden.tmpl files from the flutter_template_images repo.



Please note: some tests will not pass until we merge flutter/packages#295.
This is my first time modifying the CLI, so I'm not sure if this is the correct approach! Happy to change it up if need be.

comments.author: brianegan
comments.bodyText:
Looks like there are some test failures...

Thanks! In order for all tests to pass we need to merge and publish the corresponding template images PR. I've updated that PR based on the feedback!

This new example looks amazing! That decision doc was a great read, and the 25 spikes that led to this would be a great learning resource for the community.

Yay! Glad to hear it :)

It's probably too late, but the one thing that would really complete this, it is to show an example of arg passing. That feels like the one obvious gap from a developer POV. It feels odd that the list handler is not passing some sort of id to the detail view, and that the route generator is also not looking for it.

That was actually a really tricky call and we went back and forth on our final decision :)
In the end, to handle all of the use cases we wanted to (responsive design, web urls, etc), it felt like we had three options:

No argument passing (what we've got here)
"Hacky" argument passing -- short and sweet, but easy to break and doesn't really demonstrate how it should work
Full-featured argument passing -- Maybe a bit too much code for a template, much of it felt like it would need to be deleted or heavily modified by the end-user. Seemed better as a demonstration than a template.

My personal opinion: Navigator 2.0 handles the use cases we wanted to support, but it just requires a bit too much code right now.
The team is working on making the APIs simpler to use. Once that work has completed, the navigation patterns in this template should be updated.

Merge flutter_template_images: 3.0.0, which renames list_detail_app to skeleton: flutter/packages#310
Get any final input from the team and update this PR (all outstanding feedback so far has been addressed)
Rerun the CI checks for this PR and fix any issues. The flutter_tools pubspec for this PR already references flutter_template_images: 3.0.0, but of course no tests will pass until that's deployed.
Merge it up!

comments.author: csells
comments.bodyText: cc @stuartmorgan re: the use of non-default templates using a naming convention like "skeleton_app" or "federated_plugin" as he's particularly interested in adding a federated plugin template in the future.

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText: I think it's plausible that we'll need a couple of new *_plugin types, but I don't have a strong opinion on whether that means this needs an *_app suffix; I don't see an issue with adding *_plugin templates even if this doesn't end with _app

comments.author: filiph
comments.bodyText:
The reason I'm not 100% on board with *_app is that it's not great developer experience on the command line. flutter create -t skeleton is easy to write and remember. flutter create -t skeleton_app not so much. ("Was it skeleton_app? Or skeleton_application? Or skeletonApp?")
I do understand the appeal of having a more stratified approach to naming. I just think we need to understand the tradeoff between that, and developer experience.

comments.author: csells
comments.bodyText: Perhaps we could have a policy that non-app templates get the suffix, e.g. skeleton is an app template but instead of using federated, we use federated_plugin.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: We could also drop the underscore, as in "skeletonapp"

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
#78619 is migrating the other templates to null safety. This one probably also needs to be null save then.
/cc @mit-mit

comments.author: brianegan
comments.bodyText:
Hey all -- not 100% sure where we stand with this one. Unfortunately, I do not have any more free time to dedicate to this PR. Therefore, I'll close this one out for now.
Please feel free to pick it up if you'd like to continue with it!

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: @brianegan what was left to do? wasn't it reviewed and ready to land?

comments.author: brianegan
comments.bodyText:
It was ready to roll with the old name or "skeleton," but from what I can gather the naming discussion has not come to a conclusion and the PR has become a bit stale.
Therefore, to wrap up this work, the team needs to choose a name, update the template to support the new name, update the template to support null safety, and rebase the branch against master again as there are now conflicting changes.

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText: If someone is going to pick this up and drive it to completion please let me know soon, because otherwise flutter/packages#295 needs to be reverted as a second breaking change to that package.

comments.author: csells
comments.bodyText:
In general, this template has a ton of great practices in a very little bit of code. I'm looking forward to using it in my own projects.
Here's a little bit of review feedback for @filiph as referenced to https://github.com/brianegan/new_flutter_template:

the settings page action is hidden behind the debug banner, which could be mitigated with a tooltip
I would expect settings to be a dialog on the desktop form factor and not a page to navigate to
I normally find myself having a shared Scaffold and AppBar between pages to reduce the duplicated code while providing a consistent UI between pages
the item details page has no Settings actions
I would expect the strings "Dummy Items" and "Item Details" to be in the arb and for the code to use them
all of the tests except the first two in implementation_test.dart have great comments; would like great comments in all tests

comments.author: filiph
comments.bodyText:
Thanks @csells, replies inline:

the settings page action is hidden behind the debug banner, which could be mitigated with a tooltip

We were aware of the issue but decided to prioritize simplicity of code. What do you mean by mitigating the issue with a tooltip?

I would expect settings to be a dialog on the desktop form factor and not a page to navigate to

That would make the code a lot more complex, and isn't necessarily all that clear cut. Desktop apps often open a completely separate window for settings screens, which would make things even harder to implement.

I normally find myself having a shared Scaffold and AppBar between pages to reduce the duplicated code while providing a consistent UI between pages

We explored this. In many cases, AppBar will be meaningfully different between pages. This can be mitigated by creating a custom widget, of course, but that would make the template more complex. And it's something where we don't need to educate. The template educates about things like file structure, but extracting widget is something an intermediate developer is perfectly capable of.
In short, this goes back to the goals of the template: getting out of the way of an intermediate/advanced developer.

the item details page has no Settings actions

That is intentional. In most apps we're seeing, app-level settings aren't accessible from everywhere. Of course, a desktop app has its settings in the menu, so in that sense, it's available everywhere. But again, this is something an intermediate developer should be able to implement themselves. And it allows us to save code that would otherwise need to be understood, modified and/or deleted by the developer.

I would expect the strings "Dummy Items" and "Item Details" to be in the arb and for the code to use them
all of the tests except the first two in implementation_test.dart have great comments; would like great comments in all tests

This is also intentional. We've seen that developers, when starting projects, don't immediately implement i18n everywhere. It really damages perceived developer productivity when, instead of Text('OK') you have to write the i18n equivalent (in several files).
In the template, we show how to go about doing i18n in Flutter, and give you the files in the right places and with the right contents, but don't implement it fully for you. As a developer, you'd be deleting most of it anyway.

title: Deprecate `BoxDecoration.shape`.
author: Bernardo Ferrari

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Is it possible to somehow convert Path..addOval() to drawOval instead of drawPath? This would solve the tests.

We could consider adding void paintFill(Canvas, Rect, Paint, {TextDirection}) to ShapeBorder, whose default implementation is just canvas.drawPath(getOuterPath(rect, textDirection: textDirection))... of course then we would lose the precaching of _outerPath so that might actually be worse...

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: The biggest question is how to go from _RenderChip:<_RenderChip#c0abb relayoutBoundary=up10>  to drawCircle or something like that. If only there were a universal solution for tests. There are not many broken tests (15, only 3 are not related to switch), I just don't know how to 'improve them'.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: To fix the tests, you'll want to find the expectations that say paints..circle()..rect() or whatever, and adjust them to match what we paint now.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: cc @goderbauer who owns the framework and may have opinions on whether this is worth doing.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Luckily there seem to be only a few of these cases, but I still have no idea how to go from a RenderThing to paint. Yes, we should adjust, but how do I "print" what a Render is painting so I can compare (and possibly adjust) the test? I don't know how to do this.
Comparing BoxDecoration with ShapeDecoration, I found that ShapeDecoration ALWAYS adds Padding to Container (usually zero). Therefore, I made it null when the decorator is used + padding zero (f4088d1). Container(padding: zero) will still render as Padding(Container) (I don't know why this is wanted, but I'm not changing this behavior).

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
who owns the framework and may have opinions on whether this is worth doing.

Seems like a nice cleanup. If it does not have any performance impact, I am for this change.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Luckily there seem to be only a few of these cases, but I still have no idea how to go from a RenderThing to paint.

Ignore the Actual: line, it's just that we can't put the right thing there. It's the last bit that's relevant. It should tell you what is being rendered, and you can change the paints... expectations to call the right methods based on what it lists. So far example,  when it says:
Expected: Object or closure painting:
          'a rounded rectangle with Color(0x52000000), RRect: RRect.fromLTRBR(13.0, 17.0, 46.0,
31.0, 7.0)'
          'a circle with Color(0x33000000)'
          'a circle with Color(0x24000000)'
          'a circle with Color(0x1f000000)'
          'a circle with Color(0xfffafafa)'
  Actual: _RenderInkFeatures:<_RenderInkFeatures#61c17>
   Which: did not match the pattern.
          It called 5 other methods on the canvas, the first of which was drawPath(Instance of
'Path', Paint(Color(0x33000000))), but did not call drawCircle() at the time where a circle with
Color(0x33000000) was expected.

...you want to find where we expect(..., paints..drawCircle()) and replace it with expect(..., paints..drawPath()) (because Which: comment says it calls drawPath). Does that make sense? The more arguments you can add to these calls the better, too, since it'll test more. Look around for other tests that use paints to see what I mean.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Thanks. I'm doing this right now, already got many tests passing. Check 3cd5c23. Running flutter test locally to see what else is missing.
Edit: it seems there is only one test remaining, expansion tile. I'll check later.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Is there a way to understand what this means? I never understood the "???".
 [image: image]
 <https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/351125/180317579-5f6e2311-67ad-43be-aa43-51c5de889260.png>

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Tests now pass 😀
Next up: get some benchmark.

comments.author: bernaferrari
bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
I added a default (empty) implementation for paintBox function so it doesn't break existing code (and probably most external usage will be limited, no one will re-implement RoundedRectangleBorder).
That's it, for now.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
This sounds fantastic and I'll definitely look closer.
Thinking out loud, one option might be to have paintBox (or whatever we call it) return a boolean, default implementation returns false, and returning true means you did the work and don't need to use getOuterPath et al. That way you just always call it and don't need to have the decoupled boolean getter.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Thinking out loud, one option might be to have paintBox (or whatever we call it) return a boolean

We need to know in preCache what should be calculated and what shouldn't. So we use the boolean there, and when painting comes, we use the boolean again. For shadows, depending on the boolean, a different loop is triggered with paintBox or not, so that wouldn't work :(.
Speaking of preCache, a few late variables are now never initialized (not an issue, just kind of weird). I spent all my brain cells getting this to work. I'm counting on your review later.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: Hm yeah that's unfortunate.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Since we are optimizing things, I also committed  e91cb38 which calls drawRect when possible (when borderRadius == BorderRadius.zero). BoxDecoration only checks if borderRadius == null). It breaks a single test (chip) that we are refactoring anyway. I've wanted this change for a while, but was breaking.
Also, I asked a work colleague to help with the quick fixes, maybe until Tuesday we will have them.
Ideally, paint would be called paintBorder and paintOuterPath could be called paintInside, because it is what it is doing. I'll rename to paintInterior, it seems better (still weird it uses outerPath, not innerPath).

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Some suggestions for the docs but otherwise this looks fantastic.
Any idea why CircleBorder is still a tiny bit slower than BoxDecoration with BoxShape.circle?

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Any idea why CircleBorder is still a tiny bit slower than BoxDecoration with BoxShape.circle?

Oh, you wanted it a tiny bit faster? Consider it done.
My circle tests are based on Switch which uses shadows. Apparently if you replace shadows.map(shadows.toPaint()) + shadows.map(shadows.toRect()) with shadows.map(MapEntry(shadows.toPaint(), shadows.toRect()) it gets faster because it is one less loop (where are tuples in dart?). I can also make a list of lists; which do you prefer? [].key/[].value or [][0], [][1]?
I don't trust my benchmark, I made muuuultiple runs, the values are always changing, and I don't have a controlled environment, but it seems avoiding that loop really improves my test (300x runs with 25 switches rotating).
I also tested calling shadow.toSide() on draw time, and seems to be also faster, but caching everything ended up being even better.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: I love it.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: The quick fix is here, but it is not 100%. If you could help us fix the quick-fix, it would be great @Piinks. My colleague said he doesn't know how to go from BoxDecoration to ShapeDecoration, even when using your replaceBy. If you could take a look, should be something small.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
I split this PR in two to make it easier for you in the conflicts that might appear internally. Performance optimization + Deprecation. This is the deprecation part (the quick fix working is what's remaining). The other is already ready for review.
-- // --
Edit 1: What do you think about renaming boxShadow to shadows? This is the biggest difference between ShapeDecoration and BoxDecoration. Maybe we could deprecate that too?
--//--
Edit 2: A test requires the other change to be merged first, lol. Now I remember why they were coupled. After the other is merged, this should pass.

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
Edit 1: What do you think about renaming boxShadow to shadows? This is the biggest difference between ShapeDecoration and BoxDecoration. Maybe we could deprecate that too?

While that may be cleaner or create parity, we try to avoid changing the name of something just for the aesthetic. If it were a change that facilitated new functionality it would make more sense. Breaking changes and deprecations, in spite of the wonderful tools we have to help, affect a lot of folks, so we try to be very considerate about making them.
I am checking out your quick fixes now - thanks for including them!

comments.author: BirjuVachhani
comments.bodyText:
The quick fix to replace BoxDecoration with ShapeDecoration only works (well I was just testing the implementation visually) when we mark BoxDecoration as deprecated. In other words, If the tool can find some lint on the BoxDecoration constructor then it suggests the quick fix, otherwise it ignores it. I think that's why marking BoxDecoration as deprecated triggers the link and the quick fix.
I even tested this with dart fix --compare-to-golden . command when BoxDecoration is marked as deprecated. It passes. But without any lints on BoxDecoration, it fails.
Maybe I am missing something? I'm not sure. @Piinks Would you mind taking a look at the quick fix implementation and see if there's any issue?
Thanks.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Hey, @Piinks. The merge conflicts are "fine", the issue is I/we have no idea how to get the quick-fix working. I asked my colleague for help, and he asked yours (#108052 (comment)), but I don't think you saw that yet :(
If you could review the quick-fix again and help us get that working, it would be awesome and maybe this time we land the PR. We are struggling with it.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Is it possible to do:
BoxDecoration(
  shape: BoxShape.circle,
  border: Border.all(width: 20),
)
become
ShapeDecoration(
  shape: CircleBorder(side: BorderSide(width: 20)),
)
?
I could rename border into side, and add Border.all() inside BorderSide, but is it possible to "remove" Border.all() and keep only what's inside there?

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
I could rename border into side, and add Border.all() inside BorderSide, but is it possible to "remove" Border.all() and keep only what's inside there?

I don't think so. That is too specific and complex for the dart fix tool, and really would only account for a small number of cases. We can't account for every value a user could provide, especially since it could be abstracted into variables and method calls. The dart fix tool is meant to generally migrate folks over to the new API.

comments.bodyText: Some attributes of a TextSpan's TextStyle will be passed along to a ParagraphStyle (which is in turn used to configure the associated TextPainter) in the method mentioned in the previous comment.  Is it possible to do pass the ellipsis via this path TextStyle -> ParagraphStyle -> TextPainter instead of TextStyle -> RenderEditable -> TextPainter?

comments.author: pedromassango
comments.bodyText:
Is it possible to do pass the ellipsis via this path TextStyle -> ParagraphStyle -> TextPainter instead of TextStyle -> RenderEditable -> TextPainter?

I think it is possible (I need to do some deep research on that), however we don't have ellipsis in TextStyle currently... once this PR is merged I plan to work on #26748 so I think the change you are proposing is more suited for a different PR (the same who will fix #26748). Anyway just let me know what you think about that.

comments.author: chunhtai
comments.bodyText:
Can you apply the same method that used in paragraph_test.dart, i.e. test renderbox size?

I think I can't actually do that, because I need to test the SelectableText (or editable text widgets) and I don't have access to the paragraph in that layer.
Since the only real change I did here was to make sure the ellipsis is passed to RenderEditable class.
See my other comment for more...

comments.author: chunhtai
comments.bodyText:
I wonder if you can check the renderbox.size of the SelectableText?

comments.author: chunhtai
comments.bodyText: @LongCatIsLooong I noticed the Text widget has both textstyle and overflow parameter, do you know which one is more preferable? and whether we should sync the API between Text and SelectableText?

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
I think however we don't have ellipsis in TextStyle currently...

It looks like you're doing this ellipsis: text?.style?.overflow == TextOverflow.ellipsis ? kDefaultEllipsis : null, in RenderEditable, what I meant was, maybe you can do this in TextPainter instead? That way you don't have to add the same logic to both RenderParagraph and RenderEditable.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText:
@chunhtai https://master-api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Text/overflow.html looks like the percedence is the overflow parameter > TextStyle.overflow > DefaultTextStyle.overflow.
I personally think this kind of "cascading" makes the API more confusing (and that's one extra thing to maintain for us), especially when the Text widget already has a textStyle field. I think in Text it's fine because Text.overflow existed before TextStyle.overflow was introduced but I'd vote for not adding an overflow field to SelectableText.

comments.author: pedromassango
comments.bodyText:
I wonder if you can check the renderbox.size of the SelectableText?

Just give it a try on this. Tried to check the size of the renderbox but it seems to not change with different text size. Probably a lack of knowledge in that field, please check out the draft in https://gist.github.com/pedromassango/2fa04f07ba1a3ee42ae0e7b2aca5bc44.

It looks like you're doing this ellipsis: text?.style?.overflow == TextOverflow.ellipsis ? kDefaultEllipsis : null, in RenderEditable, what I meant was, maybe you can do this in TextPainter instead? That way you don't have to add the same logic to both RenderParagraph and RenderEditable.

Got it. I will work on that!

comments.author: MaxBittker
comments.bodyText: bravo!! thank you for fixing this long standing issue

comments.author: xiaoyanermiemie
comments.bodyText:
I wonder how panning is affected by this change. I'm mostly worried about the delta no longer being the change of the position, because this change wants to be compatible with both the iOS scrolling behavior and the iOS panning behavior. Maybe eventually we should have a "strategy" class, so that iOS monodrag, iOS panning, and Android dragging should have separate strategies.

I am confused about the iOS scrolling, the iOS panning, and the iOS monodrag what you mentioned, I am newer to iOS, after my investigation, it seems only the pan gesture is about scrolling in the picture below (Whether single finger or multiple).UIPanGestureRecognizer. Can you give me more explanation? Thank you for your patience!


Maybe eventually we should have a "strategy" class, so that iOS monodrag, iOS panning, and Android dragging should have separate strategies.

The logic in this fixed refers the iOS because the experience of iOS is better than Android. What I understand is you suggest different strategies (to simulate the Android and the iOS behavior) just like the over scroll physics behavior (the BouncingScrollPhysics and the ClampingScrollPhysics())?
Thank you for your review!

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText:
I tried it out in my app, works well 👍
FYI Pan/zoom = trackpad scrolling event. Zoom/scale is not relevant here, only pan, which could also be called scroll. When I implemented it, I summed the deltas as previous behavior, but your solution is better in my opinion. The case of using both touchscreen and trackpad is not well handled by most platforms, trying it on iOS/UIKit causes a lot of flickering and is not correct, so there isn't any break with an existing standard to change it.

comments.author: xiaoyanermiemie
comments.bodyText:
@moffatman

I tried it out in my app, works well 👍
FYI Pan/zoom = trackpad scrolling event. Zoom/scale is not relevant here, only pan, which could also be called scroll. When I implemented it, I summed the deltas as previous behavior, but your solution is better in my opinion.

Thank you for your FYI.

The case of using both touchscreen and trackpad is not well handled by most platforms, trying it on iOS/UIKit causes a lot of flickering and is not correct, so there isn't any break with an existing standard to change it.

So, the problem is the fixed only works well on the iOS and Android screens, but not on trackpad and touchscreen? I did not test on the trackpad, I will test it next week to improve. But I do not understand what's the problem with using a touchscreen, a lot of flickering on Andoird, iOS, or Windows surface? Can you give me some details about the devices to reproduce the problem? Thank you very much!

comments.author: chunfengyao

can we add the subproject logic below this line https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter_tools/templates/module/android/host_app_common/app.tmpl/build.gradle.tmpl#L33?
The reason is that the file you are changing is also used for other case where this change may or may not make sense.

In some case, the host gradle project may dependent the plugin's native module directly. and the templete may not work for this case.
such as:
We add flutter_aliplayer to flutter project's pubspec.yaml. and sync the host project's gradle file. and then we will see a native module named :flutter_aliplayer appear in module list, and then we can let host project dependent this module(sometime, this can aviod some .so library conflict).

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText:
The issue methioned by this pr only can be reproduced by running multiple build task simultaneously. And the issue was appeared Occasionally.

A test does not necessarily need to reproduce the original issue, it just has to make sure it doesn't regress. In this case you are moving the build output from a shared location to a location within the project; having an output directory within the project is a deterministic behavior that you should be able to asset.

I added a simple test file: android_plugin_multiple_build_tasks_test.dart.

A test that would not reliably fail if the issue regressed is not one that we would check in. It wouldn't actually prevent regressions, and best-case would add flake by failing rarely (which is something we explicitly don't want).

comments.author: GaryQian
comments.bodyText: @stuartmorgan  So in Gradle, the : indicates that something is a subproject of something else. :blah represents a root project, while hello:blah represents a project hello with a subproject blah. Since the code here is specifically a subproject of the root project, the .name property should not return a "path" style value with colons. Instead, subprojects of subprojects are to be found in the .subprojects property. Thus, we should not expect to find colons in subproject.name and the colon parsing/replacement is not necessary.

comments.author: stuartmorgan
comments.bodyText: Thanks for that explanation!

Instead, subprojects of subprojects are to be found in the .subprojects property. Thus, we should not expect to find colons in subproject.name and the colon parsing/replacement is not necessary.

comments.bodyText:
For everyone having trouble with travis: I used this "hack" to get travis working again.
before_script:
  - git clone https://github.com/flutter/flutter.git -b beta --depth 1
  - export PATH=./flutter/bin:$PATH  
  - cd ./flutter
  - git fetch origin pull/23397/head:pull_23397
  - git checkout pull_23397
  - cd ..

It's just checking out this pull request and using that code to run.

comments.author: dustin-graham
comments.bodyText: I'd like to say thanks to those who have been working to resolve this. However, I can't see in this thread  any identification of the root cause. My CI builder was able to build my project last week on the same version of flutter and without any local code changes. Did the external dependency move? If so, it would seem wise to see if we could get it put back where it was until this lands in Beta. Does anyone know what happened to cause this?

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText:
It's a mix of a few problems:

jcenter appears to have fallen behind Google's maven repo for a particular library.  I'm not sure why that is, but Google maven has a later version available that jcenter does not.
Gradle appears to think that because jcenter has the library but not the version, it shouldn't bother checking the next available repo - it should just assume the version is not available.
We had jcenter prioritized over google maven for finding repositories, probably for no particular reason.

The one most directly in our control to fix is item 3.  Google's maven repo should be most up to date for all Android libraries.
I'm not sure what it would take to fix this upstream in Gradle (or whether this behavior is explicitly by design - though I can't think of why that would be).  I expect jcenter will eventually catch up, unless there's some distribution issue there.

there is actually no need to merge this, although we need to upgrade the gradle version to 3.2.1 and gradle wrapper to 4.6, (...)
The file at "$flutterRoot/packages/flutter_tools/gradle/flutter.gradle" can be changed as
(...)

There are few things confused here: 3.2.1 is not a version of Gradle but Android Gradle plugin. Secondly, maven { url 'https://dl.google.com/dl/android/maven2'  } has the same effect as google() since Gradle (wrapper) 4.1. https://developer.android.com/studio/build/dependencies#google-maven

comments.author: mrmitew
comments.bodyText:
Does #23404 (comment) mean this PR should be undone?

JCenter proxies the central repository and provides additional dependencies. However, proxying seems to be broken quite regularly (there were also long threads in Twitter about it not long time ago). Its better to use google's repository directly for any artifacts that are available there and fallback to jcenter for those that do not exist. Many times in order to fix a gradle build, adding google's repo as a first option, is the way to go. Therefore, in my opinion, its better to keep the commit.

title: Added timeout for closing devfs sync http connections.
author: gaaclarke

comments.author: jmagman
comments.bodyText: Were you ever able to repro? I'd rather know what changed between 1.17 and 1.20 and track down the bug, rather than just timing out.  @zanderso was investigating this area with #54123.  There was also a lot of asset work done this release. @jonahwilliams @dnfield

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText:
Ah, that PR was something else.
As for this PR, 4 minutes sounds like an OS-level connection timeout. We might be able to bring that in by setting connectionTimeout on the HttpClient. Of course, that won't help if the client is already connected, and is timing out afterwards.
However, client request output is buffered (buffer size 8KB): https://api.dart.dev/dev/2.10.0-146.0.dev/dart-io/HttpClientRequest/bufferOutput.html, so we might not be trying to connect and send anything until the close() call.
If we think the transfer is taking too long, we should use abort() https://api.dart.dev/dev/2.10.0-146.0.dev/dart-io/HttpClientRequest/abort.html after the timeout to clean up the connection properly instead of leaking it for 4 minutes.
As @jmagman says however, it would be nice to find the root cause before adding the timeout, but adding the timeout is not terrible here since we've already got a retry loop.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Should we be using platform specific tools in order to upload binaries/assets to each device instead of HTTP? Once we have the devFS location presumably we could use something like adb push/ios-deploy something. Is that more reliable?

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Wrote up go/flutter-improving-devfs-reliability to discuss some options

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: In general I think playing with the timeouts here is a bit scary. We don't really know how long it should take to sync an asset

comments.author: gaaclarke
gaaclarke
comments.bodyText: One other thing to consider is that even if Dart fixes the http code, we will still want an apropos timeout.

comments.author: gaaclarke
comments.bodyText: It's also possible that the bug is in the devfs server.  Do we own that code?  I'm thinking it might possibly be closing a connection when it receives the payload before returning a status code, that would match my observations.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Yes, the devFS is part of the dart vm service: https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk/blob/master/sdk/lib/vmservice/devfs.dart

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: there are a few associated files there, but do note that we use the HTTP API and not the JSON-RPC API

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: I agree that fixing this may involve changing/adding timeouts, but given that we don't really seem to know the cause I'm a bit concerned that we'd just be sort of papering-over some other issue. If you can reproduce the syncing issues fairly consistently it seems like the best course of action would be to identify the actual error condition we're hitting on the device/devFS

Should we be using platform specific tools in order to upload binaries/assets to each device instead of HTTP?

I was able to capture the error in pcap:
no-response-put-devfs.pcapng.gz
The HTTP PUT is number 1547.  The server never sends us a status code back for that PUT despite having sent the data.  The retry is number 2086.

I'll add these details to the Dart issue as well.

I'm a bit concerned that we'd just be sort of papering-over some other issue

That's usually how internet protocols work, that's why there is the "Robustness principle" that dictates that we be liberal with what we accept.  That means we need to consider the fact that the server, now and in the future, may not return a status code to our PUT request.

I wonder if mock http servers can be so negligent as to not return a status code like we need... haha

You don't need to mock the server, you just need a mock client that acts like it is talking to a misbehaving server. For example, the Future returned by close() can never complete, unless there is a call to abort(), in which case it is completed with an error.

Correctness should be the primary concern here. Cherry picking something like this is especially risky, given that we don't really have integration test coverage for these sorts of failures - we'll be relying on crash reports and user issues to know if the fix worked.

Are you talking about the test that exhausts the retry count?  That isn't related to to this change.  This change has 100% test code coverage.  As far as integration tests, we actually do have them, they are in Google Test and I'm investigating them now.

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText:
Two things:

I'm suggesting adding a negative unit test as part of this change because I suspect it might shed light on the failing internal test. If you feel it would be easier to attack the failing internal test directly first, then feel free to reverse the order.
If you are feeling deadline pressure from a person or a process to get something landed quickly, then please include me wherever any relevant discussion is happening.

comments.author: gaaclarke
comments.bodyText:

Thanks, I don't want to be misunderstood I'm not trying to shirk responsibility, I'm being economical with my time and respectful of our user's time.  I have responsibilities beyond this PR.  If a task is suggested, no matter how good the suggestion is, if it doesn't advance the fixing of this issue it needs to be prioritized against all the other responsibilities I have.  In this case I don't see a reasonable theory that the suggested test will help Google Tests pass or cover an issue that could arise from the code change.  If I'm missing something please let me know.  I think it's a good idea, that's why I made the issue.
