comments.author: gaaclarke
comments.bodyText:
I printed out the times those close functions take to finish in milliseconds with the size of the payload in bytes:
request.close size:78 time: 1499
request.close size:229308 time: 1850
request.close size:61 time: 1948
request.close size:12848960 time: 5294

That's very different than the local ~10ms I was seeing.
Notice that each one is larger than the last.  I think this is an artifact of the result that we are parallelizing the sending of the files, but the server is handling them serially.  That means payload size does indirectly affect the time it takes to wait for the status code (not in network cost, but processing cost).  It also means that retry attempts will have lower likelihood of timing out as the server load lessens (assuming some tasks converge).
These tests are also running on server farms with emulated devices so I expect their numbers to be higher than anyone would experience in any sane setup.  This speaks to the need to find the root cause in the server even more.  A safe number would be 10x the observed max which would be 50 seconds, which is still better than the current 4 minute timeout.  It is hardly an acceptable pause to receive 20% of the time.

comments.author: gaaclarke
comments.bodyText: @jonahwilliams @zanderso Please give this another look.  I increased the timeout to 10 seconds based on my observations in Google Tests, trying to balance safe and considerable.  I also reduced the max inflight uploads to limit the variance in the time the request.close takes (since it appears to be waiting for the serial handling of the server of PUT requests).

comments.author: mehmetf
comments.bodyText:
@gaaclarke
Unfortunately, this had a side effect for developers deploying large apps over proxied WFH environments. There are legitimate cases where the sync takes over 10 seconds. We should either revert this or increase the timeout. I believe 60 seconds is reasonable. I would consider any dev cycle that takes over 60 seconds as unusable. See b/171005910.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: It should be safe to revert. The problem this was trying to solve was syncing assets during the initial connection, after #66742 we no longer need to sync any assets

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Increasing to 60 seconds would be a better change though, then we're not relying on the OS level timeout

comments.author: gaaclarke
comments.bodyText: #68488 increased the timeout to 1 minute.

comments.author: engine-flutter-autoroll

title: [text_input] introduce TextInputControl
author: J-P Nurmi

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
CC @LongCatIsLooong is it right that autofill should be only done for the current control?

I'm still not 100% sure about it, but I have considered autofill a visual thing because the TextInputConnection.requestAutofill() documentation states:

Requests the system autofill UI to appear.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
Thank you for the review!

I'm interested in @LongCatIsLooong's opinion from an autofill perspective.

I noticed this comment in TextInputConnection.requestAutofill() docs:
Requests the system autofill UI to appear.
It would be a problem if multiple text input controls tried to show autofill UI, which is why I ended up placing the autofill functionality to TextInputControl instead of TextInputHandler.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: (PR triage): @jpnurmi @LongCatIsLooong @justinmc Are there still plans for this before it becomes too stale?

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: I'll get back to this. I was waiting for comments/feedback because I hadn't noticed the thumbs up above.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText: @jpnurmi Can you fix the conflicts with master?  Sorry, that's probably our fault for not giving you a final review fast enough.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText: There's a failure but it looks like an infrastructure problem, rerunning...

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: Is there anything I could do to get things rolling?

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: Sorry for the delay. Looks good to me in general.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: Hi @mdebbar would you like to take a look at this? I think this change may have implications on the web.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
This PR is based on the idea that the show() and hide() methods are only called on the currently active text input control. This way, only one keyboard pops up. However, Flutter for Web requires show() to be called, or else it won't enter the editing state at all:
https://github.com/flutter/engine/blob/eb658e840d92ab4e8a9862e912ab6a4351f5aa90/lib/web_ui/lib/src/engine/text_editing/text_editing.dart#L1414
In other words, installing a custom text input control on Web blocks platform text input e.g. physical keyboard.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
Would it be an option to change it so that the editing state is controlled from setClient() and clearClient() instead, and only editing focus is set from show()?
https://github.com/flutter/engine/blob/eb658e840d92ab4e8a9862e912ab6a4351f5aa90/lib/web_ui/lib/src/engine/text_editing/text_editing.dart#L1000

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
A potential web-compatible solution:

introduce TextInputType.none in flutter/services
when a custom text input control is in use, pass "none" in the text input configuration to the platform text input control
adapt the engine for all platforms:

web: set the "inputmode" attribute to "none"
others: don't show the keyboard when the input type is "none"


bonus: it will be possible to disable the keyboard for individual TextFields

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/inputmode

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: Experimental engine changes for Linux: jpnurmi/engine@387e5c4

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: inputmode=none probably works in mobile browsers, but neither Chrome nor Firefox respects the attribute on desktop.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
Is it a blocker if Flutter for Web cannot control the on-screen keyboard on GNOME?

[1] Irrelevant? The OSK sits in a top-level window that is not auto-shown/hidden regardless of what is focused or not.
[2] Neither Chrome nor Firefox respects inputmode=none. The OSK pops up.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: I created a suggestion for TextInputType.none: #83567

comments.author: parikshitdutta
comments.bodyText:
Sorry for the delay. Looks good to me in general.

I understand there are priorities, but please fasten the review process for this one, this is an important piece of functionality for business applications, that is missing.

comments.author: mdebbar
comments.bodyText:
Thanks @jpnurmi for the PR!
The changes look good to me. I don't see any red flags that would cause issues on the web, but it would be great if you could do some sanity checks to make sure nothing is broken.
I'll leave it for @justinmc to approve the PR. This looks good from a web perspective!

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
Thanks for the review, @mdebbar!
Would you have a chance to take a look at flutter/engine#26573 too? It's the engine part i.e. TextInputType.none for web.

comments.author: LongCatIsLooong
comments.bodyText: @jpnurmi are the engine PRs prerequisites for this PR (seems to be the case from the descriptions)? If not I think we can try merging this?

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: @LongCatIsLooong I think it would be better to start with #83974 which merely introduces TextInputType.none on the framework side. It's a small standalone change and with that, it's already possible to disable VKB for individual text fields as long as the engine has the respective changes. I have a PR prepared for Web, Linux, Android, and iOS.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
@LongCatIsLooong, could you help with the following PRs, please?

TextInputType.none: #83974

Android: flutter/engine#26585
iOS: flutter/engine#26773
Linux: flutter/engine#26574
Web: flutter/engine#26573

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
Hold on. VKB buttons have started stealing focus even though they are wrapped into FocusScope(canRequestFocus: false) in the example in the docs.
EDIT: VKB buttons have started reseting focus, not stealing

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText:
The behavior was changed by commit 85be4f6:

Author: Jonah Williams jonahwilliams@google.com
Date:   Tue Jun 8 17:39:05 2021 -0700
[flutter] when primary mouse pointers don't contact a focused node, reset the focus (#82575)

packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/routes.dart       | 179 +++++++++++++++++----
packages/flutter/test/material/debug_test.dart     |   1 +
.../test/material/text_field_focus_test.dart       |  59 +++++++
3 files changed, 206 insertions(+), 33 deletions(-)

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: Hi @jonahwilliams, after #82575, is it possible to configure certain buttons to not reset focus? This particular use case is about virtual keyboard buttons that should send text editing updates to the currently focused text field.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText: @jpnurmi Are you still seeing the problem with focus here?

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
The way I would do that is introduce a companion to the FocusTrapArea which would configure the focus trap to always treat a pointer to that render object as having hit by doing a short circuit here:  https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/routes.dart#L2140
Then you could wrap your text input control in that widget to avoid loss of focus from mouse pointers

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: @justinmc I haven't looked at the new FocusTrap and FocusTrapArea widgets in-depth, but I believe a VKB input panel would need to be wrapped into something like an "inverse" focus trap area that lets focus stay where it is.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: (PR triage): @justinmc @mdebbar @LongCatIsLooong @jpnurmi Anything we can do to move this PR along?

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText: @jpnurmi It seems like you're blocked on the fact that tapping your keys removes focus, right?  I've responded with a bit of info on #86972, but we may have to come up with a separate PR to solve that issue before we can move forward here.

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: @justinmc Thanks for chiming in. The only reasonable workaround I have found is to place the VKB into an overlay. It's not that far-fetched, actually, because a real VKB is most likely laid over the content anyway. It's not the right solution to this problem, though.

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText: (Triage) This PR has not been updated in a while, and it has several merge conflicts. Should we close this until it is ready to move forward?

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Ok let's close it for now since it's blocked, though I do really want to get this merged.
@jpnurmi I'm writing a proof of concept to see if I can come up with a more flexible way to do FocusTrap.  Let's track that work on #86972, and if we can work around that, we'll reopen this PR.

comments.author: Eerey
comments.bodyText: Splendid proposal, i need this right now

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
@jpnurmi At long last FocusTrap is being removed, and the replacement seems to make it easy to create a virtual keyboard that doesn't steal focus from the text fields (#107262).  I think you'd just wrap your virtual keyboard in TextFieldTapRegion.
Are you still interested in trying to land this functionality?

comments.author: jpnurmi
comments.bodyText: @justinmc, I can confirm that it works! 🎉 What's the best way forward? Is it ok to reopen this?

comments.author: Eerey
comments.bodyText: I want/need this right now ❤️

title: InteractiveViewer Widget
author: Justin McCandless

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Notes for reviewers at this time:

I'm still adding tests.
I'm also investigating if it's possible to add mouse scrollwheel zooming at this time. Added.
Rotation is currently disabled. I did this by asserting that disableRotation is set to true in order to avoid API changes in the future.  The reason is that I likely need some time to get boundaries correct after rotation (there is a TODO in the code with more about this).
My API decision to pass-through all the GestureDetector listeners is very verbose. Is there a more concise way to achieve the same? Document for the user how to transform the coordinates themselves?  I wrote some notes about this in the PR description above. Hans helped me improve this API. See onInteraction.
There is an underlying Flutter problem with using drag targets inside of InteractiveViewer, see the PR description above.
I think the tests are failing due to the weird version error, and I need to squash all the commits. Will do that soon. Done and fixed.
Let me know if the API could be improved at all!

comments.author: HansMuller
comments.bodyText:
@justinmc - please assume that I've inserted "IMHO" below

Question: Should I default them both to 1.0 so that it doesn't zoom at all, or is that unnecessarily difficult for the user?

Making the "out of the box" use case work nicely sounds like the right way to go.

Question: Should I remove all of these listeners and document that the user needs to handle this themselves? They could use a transformationController to get the current matrix and do the inverse transform themselves.

Although I'm a big fan of low-cal APIs, providing these listeners seems like a useful convenience. On the other hand, they don't seem necessary for most apps? If they're typically not needed, since the InteractiveViewer's child will handle events directly, I think it would be best to just provide an easy way to do the transforms with the transformationController.

comments.author: HansMuller
comments.bodyText:
Rotation is currently disabled. I did this by asserting that disableRotation is set to true in order to avoid API changes in the future. The reason is that I likely need some time to get boundaries correct after rotation (there is a TODO in the code with more about this).

I think it would be reasonable to ship the first version of this widget without rotation support. The docs will need to be updated to reflect that.

edit: for a future update it might be cool to have configurable coordinate systems instead of locking it to showing 0,0 as bottom left. In my usecase I will transpose the coordinates to a Cartesian system.

comments.bodyText: Nice, I'm glad it's working!  I'll keep those two ideas in mind.  If anyone else has a need for those, please post a comment/issue so I can keep track of demand.

comments.bodyText: Any reason the _matrixScale method is private? Could be useful when trying to scale the view but keep position outside of scroll.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Just trying to keep the API minimal.  I see how it could be useful though...
Maybe any changes to transformationController should get validated based on min/maxScale and boundary.  Then users could update transformationController and still be confident that they aren't doing anything invalid.

comments.author: MichealReed
comments.bodyText:
Validation would be very helpful, I've had the view end up in some strange places. How would you recommend setting the scale of the view/"zoom"? Maybe a simple scale update API for the controller that keeps the view position would make sense over revealing _matrixScale on the widget.
edit: Any example/workaround in the mean time to modify the scale without affecting the view position?

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Putting it on the controller is a great idea actually.  What is your use case for wanting to programmatically zoom?  Are you zooming in on a specific point on your child or something like that?
See how InteractiveViewer handles a scale gesture here. It's actually a scale plus a translate in order to keep the focal point of the gesture at the same place on the screen.  That's why it appears to zoom in on the point where you pinch (or where the mouse cursor is).

comments.author: MichealReed
comments.bodyText:
I'm going to persist the user's view/scale on a board and restore it upon return. May also include a spectator style experience in the future which would require spectators to follow updates from the host.
I was looking at that section earlier and noticed that I would have to reimplement _matrixScale and _matrixTranslate among other things to use in conjunction with the widget. Understand if it's the only workaround until a scale API can be added.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText: Restoring an existing state sounds like something you could use transformationController directly for.  You could get the Matrix4 to save the state and then set it again to restore it.  See the example in the transformationController docs which shows something similar, including an animation.

comments.author: not-holar
comments.bodyText: I think mouse scrollwheel zoom directions should be reversed so that scrolling up zooms in and scrolling down zooms out. Most applications do it this way so it's more intuitive for users.

comments.author: not-holar
comments.bodyText: Also it doesn't seem to respond well to constraint changes (At least when resizing the window on Windows).

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
@not-holar You seem to be right about both of these.
Here's a PR to reverse scroll zoom direction: #60523
And here's a PR to update the boundaries when child size changes: #60532
That second PR seems to greatly improve behavior after the screen size changes.  I imagine there could still be edge cases that don't feel right though.  Let me know if you see anything else.

comments.author: MichealReed
justinmc
MichealReed
comments.bodyText:
Opened #60550 to cover.
The planned builder will help when the user is zoomed, the general concept of a builder here reminds me of Occlusion Culling (https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/OcclusionCulling.html). It may not help when the user is completely zoomed out though as it will still need to render a significant number of cells and the viewer can be customized to allow for large views, but prevent max scale thus still allowing scroll/pan. ListViews and GridViews have it easier and don't have to tackle the scale aspect.
Although skia fixes the crashing related to text and increases performance significantly, I am still seeing fps drop and jank when using it, especially on mobile. If there's anything low hanging for performance on the widget side that you could change, that would be awesome.
using
flutter run -d chrome --web-hostname=lanIP --web-port=8080 --dart-define=FLUTTER_WEB_USE_SKIA=true --release
to deploy and access via mobile browsers.
edit: I believe the repaint issue to be separate. I can't think of any other widget that impacts scale like the InteractiveViewer, and it may have uncovered/be connected to issues with how flutter handles scaling. A bit over my head currently, but I have a hunch.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Thanks for opening that issue, I'll try to see if there are any quick improvements to make.
One thing I've been thinking about recently related to the scale problem.  Currently, as a user of InteractiveViewer, you could listen to the current zoom level by adding a listener to transformationController and looking at transformationController.value.getMainScaleOnAxis().  If the zoom level is below a certain value (meaning zoomed out), you could pass a simplified version of your child to InteractiveViewer.  I wrote a demo sort of like that recently.

comments.author: MichealReed
comments.bodyText: Ah very cool, I can use that to pause animations. I could also implement an LOD system based on this to downscale assets. Great idea, let me know if any others come to mind.

Is it somehow possible to set the current scale or offset of the InteractiveViewer from outside the widget? Eg. by a GlobalKey etc.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText: Yes, using transformationController.  There's an example in the docs there that should get you started, but you can set the matrix like transformationController.value = myMatrix. The Matrix4 class has some useful methods for working with the matrix.

Thank you, @justinmc. For future people having the same issue:
transformationController.value = transformationController.value.scaled(myCustomScale);

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
This will be a subtile breaking change for people that relied on the fact that the animation doesn't run.

Could this allow for perhaps the option to choose which behavior you would like? If so, you could leave the current behavior as the default, and it would not be breaking.

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText:
This will be a subtile breaking change for people that relied on the fact that the animation doesn't run.

Could this allow for perhaps the option to choose which behavior you would like? If so, you could leave the current behavior as the default, and it would not be breaking.

My concern with this is that it would be accepting broken behaviour as the default. Since these methods represent a 'push and...' transition, future developers should be able to expect a normal push animation and not be required to opt-in to it. Agreed that it might be a breaking change for some that opted to work around the problem rather than post a fix, but think default behaviour should be correct and favour future developers, in which case the break for the few may be necessary. Hopefully those that were relying on the broken feature should have accepted that it is likely to be fixed at some point in the future?
If we introduce optional behaviour, should this be unique to the 'push and...' operations? or for consistency should the secondaryAnimation be optional for other operations such as push() too? It feels contrary to the purpose of exposing the secondaryAnimation to transition builders to use if/as they see fit if there is an option somewhere else to determine if secondaryAnimation is just a dummy parameter - how would the transition builder know if it is a dummy and using it would have no effect?
I'm happy to amend to introduce more functionality, just want to make sure we fix what is broken rather than treat it as an unintended feature.

comments.author: dellgreen
comments.bodyText: if it is agreed that the expected default behaviour is currently broken, then if its made opt in (to not break current releases), provision should be made to change the default behaviour (i.e to opt out) with the next major iteration where breaking changes would normally be allowed. :)

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText: It is also unlikely that this will break anyone's code - if they are relying on the parameter having no effect, they would surely not be trying to use it. In which case, making the parameter they are not using live should make no difference.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: I think it is reasonable to make this breaking change. In order to do so, please check the breaking change box in the PR description and follow the process linked from there.

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText: Update of the branch resulted in a failing test in routes_test.dart. Would appreciate any feedback on the addition to navigator to resolve the fail - both the replaced route and the preceding route secondary animations are now updated. This results in the preceding route secondaryAnimation being a TrainHoppingAnimation, required for when the preceding route is still visible when the replacement happens on the history head. Hopefully this is correct.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: I don't fully understand you last comment. Seems like all tests are passing now?

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText:
Yes all tests passing now - hopefully nearly ready to get this on master.
To try explain my last comment better... if you have a stack A, on which you push B, then replace B with C (all before the B push animation is finished)...
Before the PR = A secondaryAnimation was updated (via a TrainHoppingAnimation) to proxy C animation, B was unaffected
My original PR = B secondaryAnimation was updated to proxy C animation, A unaffected
Now = both. A secondaryAnimation proxies C animation (via TrainHoppingAnimation), AND B secondaryAnimation proxies C animation
Which seems right to me :)

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText: Our breaking change policy has been updated as of a few days ago. We'll need to make sure this follows the new policy before it can land. https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Tree-hygiene#handling-breaking-changes

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText:
Hi @Piinks. I think the change to breaking change policy might actually help this PR. Based on discussion before, I believe this PR probably falls into this category now:

Changes that don't break any tests and which, while technically breaking, are in our judgement unlikely to cause much trouble. We will pretend that such changes are not breaking changes and make them without any effort to prevent breakages.

The change doesn't brake any tests (all tests involved in this PR are entirely new) and is unlikely to create anyone any issues (only if you were using a secondaryAnimation parameter that you were relying on not being active - which wouldn't make sense, you'd just not use it).
What do you think?

comments.author: goderbauer

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText:
@chunhtai yes, on review I agree that it is probably wrong to notify after the transition. Since pushAndRemoveUntil() already had the mechanism to notify after the transition, I carried it across into pushReplacement(). I was reluctant to remove it from pushAndRemoveUntil()  as I do not know why it was put there in the first place other than that it was part of a 'pushAndRemoveUntil() fix' (commit message). We require notification before to ensure secondary animations behave correctly, and I also believe subsequent actions should responsible for change notifications (no tests fail if it is removed)
I will therefore remove the 'after' notifications from both methods. @Piinks - looks like you might have introduced/edited the pushAndRemoveUntil()'s didChangeNext()  notification after the transition. Would you agree it is safe to remove? It's only a revert away if not.

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText:
Unsurprisingly, I have lost track of the coming and goings of the notifications of previous/next throughout this PR, and apologies if I have placed back in what was originally agreed to be out and so on.
I think we currently agree that all notifications are correct at the onset of the transition, and that a new transition would always setup all the previous/next states as necessary.
The only issue left is what to do at the end of the transition. Since these are transitions specifically to push a route and then change the history behind it, it felt reasonable for the new route to complete the transition in a state where the change in its history is recognised. This is subject to the new route still existing, and that the history could have changed during the transition. I recognise that this final previous notification is not necessary to resolve the specific PR issue, it just felt right.
If it will land the PR, I will happily remove lines 1892-1895 and 1970-1973, but to make sure this is the final commit, please can somebody make a definitive decision that they shouldn't be there, or that they can remain. Either way passes all tests.

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
I've seen this versioning issue happen with old branches. I recently resolved this by locally using
git fetch upstream
git reset --soft upstream/master
git commit ...  (recommit all changes)
git push -f ... (force push to remote branch)
This would reset the history of your commits though, and combine them all into the new commit. @dnfield thought this might be a pub issue?  It seems to be cropping up in more places.

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText:
@jonahwilliams
I'm fairly certain this is an issue with how the tool resolves the version.  It uses git tags and commit history to do it, and we're probably getting into a state here where it can't resolve the version correctly.
See these lines:
 The current Flutter SDK version is 1.10.7-pre.130.

    | 

    | Because flutter_gallery depends on video_player_web >=0.1.1 which requires Flutter SDK version >=1.12.8 <2.0.0, version solving failed.

It should be saying the current flutter SDK version is 1.14.x-pre.something, not 1.10.7-pre.130.

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText: In the mean time, yes, redoing your git history should work around it.

comments.author: chunhtai
comments.bodyText: @joellurcook I left a comment a while back. Would like to bump it up to get your attention :)

comments.author: joellurcook
comments.bodyText:
@chunhtai hi sorry, don't know how I missed that comment!
Good catch - I had forgotten about the Cupertino label. I don't think we can risk calling both back-to-back, though. This is fine for the situation where we have routes A-B-C and C replaces B - C label will end up indicating A, after very briefly indicating B.
But what if C replaces A and B? in that case, C label will indicate B (precedingRoute), there is no newPrecedingRoute. The result is then a route pointing back to a route that doesn't exist. This isn't something we should fix after the transition either, as it should animate in with the correct value.
Therefore, I suggest that it is safe (and necessary) for both precedingRoute and newPrecedingRoute to have next pointing to newRoute, but that newRoute previous should only be set to the ultimate preceding route (if any).
It is confusing that B->C but A<-C, but think it is necessary. Hopefully you can clean up the terminology in the larger refactor.
Hope that all makes sense!

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText:
I think this is a mistake in the doc.  In fact, at this point I think I should just get rid of the clampTop parameter entirely - it was there before I had a better way to control whether the sheet was going to be persistent or not.
The problem is that once you introduce a non-dismissable bottom sheet, you really should not be introducing any more bottom sheets unless they're modal.  It causes weird problems with trying to figure out which sheets to leave open or close or to show hte user.  The right way to show a persistent bottom sheet is to set it as a property on the Scaffold, where we can manage things better.
What do you think of that idea?

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText:
Mainly writing this down now so I don't forget - there are three "larger" items from this review so far I'm hoping to get greater clarity on:

I'm not sure how to avoid using the screen height.  I agree route height would be better, but we can't access that or even the constraints at build time, which is when we need it. I think the Scaffold layout delegate could maybe expose it back to us, but I'm worried about that getting very messy.
Right now I'm using 2 pixels as "close enough" to just treat things like we've reached the top as far as hiding the FAB goes.  I suspect there's a better way to handle this, but I'm not quite sure what.
I moved the PostFrameCallback to a (hopefully) more sensible location (didChangeDependencies on BottomSheetState) - however, I can't come up with a good and safe way to visit the children to see if we're ok instead of just asserting the scroll controller got a client after a frame.

comments.author: gspencergoog
comments.bodyText:
The Diagnosticable seems reasonably big. Do we expect a random number after BorderSide now?

We use Diagnosticable on all the widgets, and many other classes, to handle formatting of the debug strings in a consistent way.  The "random number" is part of the object hash, so that you can tell if two instances of the object are the same instance or not.  It's not big in the runtime sense: it doesn't have any data members, and only costs something when toString is called, which is only used in debug builds anyhow.

Ok. I think there only two things left:

What happens with RoundedRectangle + Border zero.

I'd say it should not jump in the lerp. And you're talking about the case where the strokeAlign is "outside", not the default case of "inside", right? Because I think that for rounded rects, it's expected that the rounded edge appears as it goes outside, since it inflates the rect. We could do some kind of crazy thing where we draw values less than 2 pixels differently from the rest of the values, making the "outside" alignments draw a progressively sharper rectangle as they approach zero. comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
@TahaTesser following up from flutter/website#7243 it looks like there may be a bug here, but I am not sure..
Using the default ThemeData() constructor will result in default values for toggleableActiveColor:
light mode: ThemeData.accentColor ?? ThemeData.primarySwatch[600]
dark mode: Colors.tealAccent[200]
and ThemeData.primarySwatch would default to Colors.blue if null.
It looks like this constructor does not set the ColorScheme.secondary when a colorScheme is not provided. Since ColorScheme.secondary is the new default for radio buttons, should it reflect these colors in this case? Or does it already? I found this while migrating a customer.

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText: Of course! No worries - and I could be wrong. Migrating theme info for customers is always tricky. They could have multiple themes defined anywhere in their app, so it could be that there is no bug here. It's just worth double checking on a breaking change.

comments.author: TahaTesser
comments.bodyText:
Hey @Piinks

Using the default ThemeData() constructor will result in default values for toggleableActiveColor:
light mode: ThemeData.accentColor ?? ThemeData.primarySwatch[600]
dark mode: Colors.tealAccent[200]
and ThemeData.primarySwatch would default to Colors.blue if null.

I looked into this.
If you look at the specs https://material.io/components/switches#theming, ColorScheme secondary is the only color to be used. Colors defined in toggleableActiveColor are hard coded. Looks like it was created when ThemeData.primarySwatch was more prominent part of the theme system, now it is largely ignored.
IMO, this migration doesn't need to be compatible with ThemeData.primarySwatch since it is also need to be deprecated.
theme_data largely ignores primarySwatch when brightness is set to dark and Darren Austin's comment  also indicates ColorScheme colors should be default (matching Material specs here too).

In this case they are broken because ColorScheme.secondary is a different default.

IMO, ColorScheme.secondary is slightly lighter blue by default hence the difference (also native switch is ligher too compared to the one created using `toggleableActiveColor but it is a spec accurate color regardless of the theme brightness (ColorScheme.secondary). In fact track color is even lighter in native Android.



Flutter
Android










Since ColorScheme.secondary is the new default for radio buttons, should it reflect these colors in this case?

I think widgets should reflect ColorScheme.secondary.

It looks like this constructor does not set the ColorScheme.secondary when a colorScheme is not provided.

Default ColorScheme.secondary color  is returned when no colorScheme is provided. Widgets are still blue when you don't define ColorScheme.
    return const MaterialApp(
      debugShowCheckedModeBanner: false,
      home: Example(),
    );
In cases where  ColorScheme.secondary is already defined but it is a different color than what is defined in ThemeData.toggleableActiveColor, app should not break since fix overrides the component themes to match existiing toggleableActiveColor, if component is already defined, fix applies .copyWith and adds toggleableActiveColor color for each widget.

It's just worth double checking on a breaking change.

Agreed. Without looking at specific customer tests, i cannot say if this is deal breaker and how to overcome this if needed but looking the specs and deprecate primarySwatch issue. I cannot find anything else to fix here.

title: Scan assets from disk
author: fmatosqg

comments.bodyText:
@fmatosqg actually, see the discussion in #14246.  The fix to google/file.dart#68 just landed (and as of #16442 is rolled into Flutter), so the right answer is actually to update the asset tests to use MemoryFileSystem, with a style of FileSystemStyle.windows for the windows tests.
/cc @goderbauer

comments.author: fmatosqg
comments.bodyText:
@tvolkert I'm going on a rabbit hole, I'd appreciate some guidance.

Should I replace all instances I find of fs.file(), fs.isFileSync() etc with something coming from MemoryFileSystem ? If yes, removing import 'base/file_system.dart'; from all related files is the way to get started and find all offending uses?
Should I use FileSystemStyle.windows for all build systems, and if not how would I do the check?
can I still use getReplaySource('', 'a/b/c') on windows or do I need to go through URI conversion, and how?

comments.author: tvolkert
comments.bodyText:
Sorry - I started reviewing the PR, and before we dive too deeply in fixing the tests, let's take a step back on the design.
Rather than having a enable-asset-scan attribute in the pubspec, I think we should just respect asset entries that follow a certain pattern, such as:

Any entry that ends with a slash is treated as a directory, and we include all files within the directory (recursively)
We support globstar-style syntax (the pattern ‘**’ used in a filename expansion context will match all files and zero or more directories and subdirectories.)

comments.author: fmatosqg
comments.bodyText:
@tvolkert Thanks for review, some feedback on feedback:
That makes sense, though I'm not sure how to interpret some entries with globstar on variants.
I'm not familiar with globstar so I'll draft some unit tests right here.
Consider these files:
a/file
a/b/file
a/b/c1/file
a/b/c2/file


If I aim at a/ then we should get asset a/file with variant a/b/file
If I aim at a/b/**/ it's still easy to tell but tricky to implement, asset is a/b/file and it has 2 variants a/b/c1/file and a/b/c2/file
Now if we do a/**/ things get messy and I don't know how to tell variants from main assets.

Another example:
disk is
d/e/file


Importing d/ will get asset file without main asset d/file but with variant d/e/file
Importing d/e/ is still unambiguous, asset d/e/file without a variant
But d/**/ could mean either.

Can you show some places where globstar is supported? If they also deal with variants I can try to see how they behave.
Pls advise.

comments.author: tvolkert
comments.bodyText:

Basically, it takes a raw listing of asset files (split out by package) and deduces which are the base assets versus the variants.

to clarify the ambiguous example with realistic file names
given the following files
./assets/1.png
./assets/2.0x/1.png
./assets/3.0x/1.png
./assets/3.0x/2.png

Option A:

assets:
  - assets/1.png
  - assets/2.png

  - assets/

Option B:

assets:
  - assets/

code will fail on analyzer
flutter_manifest_test.dart should pass any unit tests
asset_bundle_package_test.dart should fail only on tests that involve MemoryFileSystem, the fix I was thinking is make testUsingContextAndFs public (from flutter_manifest_test.dart or a new file) and simply reference them.

Reminder, pending checking/doing something on asset.dart needsBuild() for the situation where
1.1 app is running with debug
1.2 developer adds/removes file to a scanned path (I'm almost sure it works but not sure on bad side effects)
2.1 full build
2.2 developer adds/removes file to scanned path
2.3. full build again, no clean. (observing AssetManifest.json and files copied to android intermediate folder will probably tell everything - I think it will work easier for adding files but removing them may be tricky)

comments.bodyText: likewise 🥇

title: [flutter_tools] support code size tooling on iOS, linux, windows, macOS, and Android on Windows
author: Jonah Williams

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Oh woops, I need to update the linux rule too

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
Some notes:
With multiple ABIs we generate multiple size analysis files, but silence the terminal output for anything besides the first  since it is redundant.
I don't output anything for the other platforms (yet) since I'm not sure what format they should take
Terminal output doesn't look correct for very long lines. Probably need to change it from being hard-coded
The apk_analysis_01.json files should probably be named according to the ABI
Still doesn't work on windows
The other platforms do not have a reasonable "compressed" size to measure yet, so I just use the size on disk

comments.author: kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText: DBC - can we generate a Dart AOT snapshot for each ABI, swap it out for the corresponding libapp.so node in the APK, and output a single apk-analysis.json file with all this data? This seems like it would be the easiest route for the user, who would then only have to worry about a single file to drop in to devtools, where they'd be able to filter and look at different ABIs.

comments.author: kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText:
Some general questions:


Can you add some details to the PR description explaining what it now looks like to run the --analyze-size command and what the output structure looks like?


How many architectures (not sure what the correct term is e.g. ABI for Android) are there for iOS?


What if we output a single file per platform, where each file contains all the data for each available architecture (e.g. 1 Dart AOT snapshot for each libapp.so file)?


android-analysis.json
ios-analysis.json
linux-analysis.json
macos-analysis.json
windows-analysis.json

comments.author: jonahwilliams
kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText:
DBC - can we generate a Dart AOT snapshot for each ABI, swap it out for the corresponding libapp.so node in the APK

No, we can't drastically change the output of flutter build apk - though we could recommend split-per-abi work well ( I haven't looked at it yet).

If flutter build apk is ran without a target ABI specified, we get libapp.so files for all platforms, correct? I'm suggesting that we generate a v8 snapshot for each ABI, and add the output to the apk-analysis.json file as the libapp.so node (like we currently do for the default ABI we generate the AOT snapshot for)

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
Ahh okay, I think I get it then. Let me take a poke at that, I will have some more question.
This is sort of related to iOS too - there are potentially two ABIs, but they are lipo'd into a universal binary

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: I don't really see a good way to update the multiple ABI cases without rewriting a lot of the assumptions about the analysis structure. I need to time box this due to perf, @kenzieschmoll WDUT about multiple output files?

comments.author: kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText: I'm fine with multiple output files to start - though eventually I think it would be cleaner if we just output a single file. Can we do something to require that a user specifies the target platform/arch when using the --analyze-size flag? This will help eliminate confusion about the APK total size when it includes multiple libapp.so files.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Yeah, restricting the output seems reasonable.

comments.author: xster
comments.bodyText:
optional nit: can we print the number on the next line or apply some cosmetic treatment when the line is longer than the indent for the size?
Also, we should definitely save the full tree into the JSON but for the CLI output, I think it would be good to reduce the tree depth and collapse sections (such as just Resources as a single entry etc)

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
I was thinking we could trim the leading path segments up to the actual asset name.

I think it would be good to reduce the tree depth and collapse sections (such as just Resources as a single entry etc)

asset sizes are definitely important, but yeah the output is a bit overwhelming on the gallery. Perhaps we could collapse over some threshold?

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
Yeah, I'm not so sure about the CLI output in general. I think given time constraints, we could remove most of it except for maybe the top level dart libraries.
None of the other platforms have any meaningful compressed size either

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Compared to not supporting our most popular platform/host combo it isn't that bad. 🤷‍♂️

comments.author: xster
comments.bodyText: I'm not against it 😂 I'm just being facetious

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: @kenzieschmoll is there some additional processing happening in package:vm_snapshot_analysis? I noticed we don't seem to get a more detailed breakdown for flutter or the current package name.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: @xster AAR is kind of weird, we build debug/profile/release all at once - I'm not sure the best way to make it clear that the code size analysis would only be fore release. I'm going to skip that one and someone can come back to it later

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Lots of churn on this one, but I think it is ready for another look. I would appreciate it if someone with access to the code-size tooling could sanity check the output for some of the non-APK analysis.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: (The windows tool tests failure is expected, I need to rebase)

I still think it's a bit much and we should collapse it. Since it spans so many pages, it's hard to glance at the CLI output and know what to do with it. The CLI output should be a summarizing signal for users to look one page and be like, oh sounds reasonable, or oh assets seem larger than expected, let's open devtools.
At least it should show sums per directory instead of only sizes of each individual file.

comments.author: kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText: On your second to last comment with console output (the iOS or macos one i think), shouldn't Dart AOT symbols accounted decompressed size be a direct child of App (Dart AOT)? Similarly for the windows output in the PR description, having Dart AOT symbols accounted decompressed size be a sibling or, in the mac case, a node on a higher level is confusing. As a user I would think, "there are two things that say Dart AOT, which one is the Dart AOT snapshot"?

comments.author: kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText: I agree with you jonah - the CLI output is too busy. It's hard to parse any useful information from that because it's just information overload. User's should go to DevTools for detailed analysis.

comments.author: kenzieschmoll
comments.bodyText: this cl also fixes #63676

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: I guess i could see myself using the output, but yeah it could definitely be intimidating.  That said, if we provide too brief of a summary, then there is little point in providing any output at all.

comments.author: xster
comments.bodyText: I think collapsing at this level (per first level directory (have to tweak level per platform since iOS/macOS chain is long by default) except the path leading to the AOT) is reasonable. It's essentially a split by content type (assets, dex, .so, resources, etc).

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Updated to collapse more information, and to rename output to *-code-size-analysis.json

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
To reduce make the 10 limit more useful, we could:

collect all of the dart:* libraries into a single node
hide the @whatever entries

WDUT @xster

comments.author: xster
comments.bodyText:
ya, you're right. The top 10 as-is is probably a bit non-distinctive across projects.
I'm tempted to say leaving Dart split might be a helpful treeshaking verification too (i.e. I'm guessing those numbers would change around as I write my app different?).
I'm also tempted to say that having the user be able to glance at something that fits in a screen could be useful too.
How about top 20 or something like show 30 but up until the package still <10kb?
Anyway, it's increasingly nit at this point. Feel free to decide.

        src                                                                 7 KB
      package:scoped_model/
        scoped_model.dart                                                   5 KB

I'm going to call that good for now

title: Add FormField validation states (touched, saved, etc) with ErrorStateMatcher
author: Yumin Chen

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText: @justinmc @HansMuller Could you take a look at this PR please? 😃

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Thanks for the PR!  This is definitely a really high quality PR, but I want to make sure it's the right approach for solving this sort of problem.
Is there anything that you can do with this approach that can't be done currently?  You can do some similar stuff with onSaved and onTap.  See this Dartpad for example: https://dartpad.dartlang.org/27082245d18da32b35f71a026ed1dc7a

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
Is there anything that you can do with this approach that can't be done currently?

The separation of hasError (whether the input is valid) and isErrorState (whether error should be shown) can be a useful distinction for many modern UX design use cases. There are often times when we want to find out if the input is valid (with the validator) without necessarily having to show the error message to the user. With autovalidate and errorStateMatcher, this approach can keep hasError always up to date and always reflects the validity of the input while not showing the error, and this is something we currently cannot do easily.
Furthermore, this type of error-after-touch form field is quite common in today's UX design. I'd even argue that it makes sense to become the default behavior of a form field out of the box. This errorStateMatcher approach can provide an easy and convenient way to implement this without having to use any state variable or any repetitive logic. I'd hate having to copy a bunch of boilerplate code and repeat the touched checking logic for every simple form field I implement.
As pointed out in #18885 by others, the lack of this feature marks a notable feature parity between Flutter and Angular, and adding this can help bridge the feature gap.

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
This is a very welcome addition!
I do currently use something like @justinmc attached, but this would be nice to have out of the box, or even as a default behaviour as @chen-yumin suggests.
I'm not sure if this PR makes #48948 unnecessary?

comments.author: tjonganthony
comments.bodyText:
just putting my two cents here:
I feel that ErrorStateMatcher is duplicating what validator is supposed to be doing.
From how I see it, we have 2 different issue, which I have elaborated in #48874 and #48876.
To summarise: we should be able to know whether a Form/Field is valid without changing the UI. Another one is on the behaviour of autovalidation, which validate even before Field is touched(Additionally, this is inconsistent with Form's autovalidation as described in #48876).

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
I feel that ErrorStateMatcher is duplicating what validator is supposed to be doing.

I might not have worded their functionality clearly. Here is a comparison. They are very different:




validator
errorStateMatcher




Purpose
defines the condition whether field is valid.
defines the condition whether errors should be shown to the UI.


Example
validator: (password) => password.length < 6 ? "Error" : null,
errorStateMatcher: (field) => field.touched,



An example of a password field could use both:
TextFormField(
      autovalidate: true,
      obscureText: true,
      validator: (password) => password.length < 6 ? "Error msg" : null,
      errorStateMatcher: (field) => field.touched,
);
Without the errorStateMatcher, we'd have to use something like @justinmc attached, which is not only more verbose, but it also mixes the UI error showing logic (whether errors should be shown to UI) with the validation logic (whether field is valid).

We should be able to know whether a Form/Field is valid without changing the UI.

Totally agree. It is not nice to have to put touched check in the validator, because that would mix the UI logic with the actual validation. They should be separate, -- thus the need for a separate custom function to let user define the condition whether errors should be shown to the UI.

Edit: I've edited the main thread and added the comparison and examples too.

comments.author: tjonganthony
comments.bodyText:
I do understand the difference between errorStateMatcher and validator.
However I feel that it is not the right approach to solve the problem we're facing as it causes FormField to have 2 properties that determines whether error is shown, which further complicate the widget.
Additionally, errorStateMatcher will have more complication in some workflow.
Let's say we have 15 fields with validation. We only want to show user the error if:

user touched the field
or user clicks on the submit button, where we will call Form.validate() and decide whether to proceed or show all the error
In second case, all of the Field that hasn't been touched will not show an error because it has never been touched. Now we need to set all FormFieldState.touched to be true which is actually not semantically correct.

I feel that we should focus on what we want to achieve: to be able to not show error before the field is touched(which is also discussed separately in #48993).
For what it's worth, I can't foresee other cases needing errorStateMatcher besides checking whether the field has been touched.

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText: For the scenario with the submit button, you could set errorStateMatcher: (field) => field.saved || field. touched, and on submit call save, then the error will all show up upon save.

comments.author: tjonganthony
comments.bodyText:
I'm not saying it's not possible at all.
You just proved a point where you need to keep modifying errorStateMatcher and further complicate it with more state. Calling save is also a hack that you're using in order to leverage on an existing state.
The proposal I discussed in both issues involves calling form.validate() that does not change the existing behaviour at all, and additional property in FormField, instantlyValidate: false(tentative naming). Which is a more straightforward approach I believe.

comments.author: HansMuller
comments.bodyText:
If I'm understanding this correctly, what's needed is a way to defer highlighting invalid autovalidate: true fields until after the user has entered a value.  Presumably this is a common case.
The approach Justin suggested works, but it requires one to mixup validation logic and a flag that indicates that the user has entered a value.
The approach suggested here seems more general than is needed (do we really need to control this behavior on a per-field basis?) and "errorStateMatcher" doesn't seem like a particularly evocative name.
Would it be sufficient to add a flag to Form that defers highlighting invalid fields until the user has provided input?

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
@HansMuller just to clarify:
We definitely don't want to trigger the errors before user has even started typing.
Next question is, do we want to start validation "on touched" or "on saved"
My preference is "on saved", since on touched would make the error appear before user had a chance to finish the input. I think there should be a way to choose the "mode".
Maybe having something like an enum would be a good solution:
AUTOVALIDATE_ALWAYS,
AUTOVALIDATE_ON_TOUCHED
AUTOVALIDATE_ON_SAVED

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
@HansMuller  Yes, that's correct. That's exactly the problem this is trying solve here.

do we really need to control this behavior on a per-field basis?

That's a very good point. I think per-form basis would make more sense. Since autovalidate is supported both on the form and form field, we could support both here too.

"errorStateMatcher" doesn't seem like a particularly evocative name.

True. We can come up with a better name if we decide this approach is OK. The ErrorStateMatcher is borrowed from Angular.

Would it be sufficient to add a flag to Form that defers highlighting invalid fields until the user has provided input?

I think the solution @SpajicM proposed is good. Yes, we definitely need to let the user customize when they want the auto validation to perform, but I'd like to cover at least the following 4 cases:

always (current behavior)
touched
saved
(touched || saved)  => The use case @tjonganthony pointed out earlier is a good example of when (touched || saved) can be quite useful.

If we could cover the above 4 cases then the flag should be efficient for most use cases IMO.
However, I do think the concept of having an errorStateMatcher can offer more flexibility because the user can have their custom-defined variables in there. (e.g. they could implement the case of showing error on blur, when the field loses focus, using the custom function). If we could offer a custom function, that'd be a great addition IMO.

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
The use case of showing error on blur (on losing focus) is actually quite common too. I often times notice error message only show up after I switch to the next field, or click outside the input field. If we do go ahead with a flag, shouldn't we try to cover this too? Also the case of (onBlur || onSaved)? In this case, I think a custom function would work the best.
I can already think of 7 common cases:

always (current behavior)
touched
blurred (lose focus)
saved
(touched || saved)
(blurred || saved)
never (always hide error from UI, but the logic remains)

Would a flag be sufficient in this case?

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
@chen-yumin
Blur case is also quite nice to cover, I agree.
The way I see it, flag enum is more intuitive and clean to use, while error state matcher offers more flexibility.
The Flutter wiki states:
"Avoid implementing features you don’t need."
If we go by that, enum is a better solution.
Not sure if we could use bitwise operator | to combine the flags. That would bring down the count to 5.

comments.author: tjonganthony
comments.bodyText:
Can we use separate flag instead of using bitwise or enum?
i.e make the parameter to be:
this.validateOnStart = true, // to not break the existing behaviour
this.validateOnTouch = false,
this.validateOnEdit = true,
this.validateOnBlur = false,

Then we can start deprecating autovalidate since the word auto is ambiguous anyway.
I actually feel that we should remove the behaviour of a field immediately during build, but I don't know how we feel on making breaking change.

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
Why do you prefer this over enum?
I feel these options should be grouped somehow.
And about breaking change, I'm against it unless absolutely necessary.

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
@tjonganthony Are you suggesting that we have multiple parameters for the same feature?
Agreed with @SpajicM here. I'd prefer a single flag parameter over having multiple ones, or at least we should group them together as a single parameter.
I don't think we can use bitwise operations to combine enum flags in Dart. Currently, Dart does not support enum with values (dart-lang/language#158). So unfortunately not with an enum -- a workaround would be using a class with static members, but that's a different discussion now.
I do like the flag with bitwise operation syntax though. It reminds me of the good old Win32 programming days when most windows params are set with flags combined with bitwise operations.

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
I'm still not too convinced with using a flag here, because:

For situations when you want to use multiple logical operators (&&, ||, and !) together to define the condition to show error.
For example: If I want to show errors when (touched && blurred) || saved, there is no easy way you can define this with a flag. This is an example of when the we don't want to show errors just on blur, but also make sure it's been touched. The && operator can avoid the situation when the user was just tabbing through (switching between input fields) without editing anything.
There are quite a few cases we need to cover, as stated above, and they might need to be combined with multiple logical operators (&&, ||, and !) creating even more permutations with more flags.
Using bitwise operators to combine flags is nice, but currently Dart does not support Enum with values (dart-lang/language#158). Also, I don't often encounter the syntax of enum flags with bitwise operators in Dart, especially within Flutter. It is questionable if we should encourage this syntax.

Your thoughts?

comments.author: tjonganthony
comments.bodyText:
@SpajicM I was thinking it may have easier usability and more "backward compatible". As @chen-yumin mentioned, we may need to add more granular behaviour in the future that may interact with other behaviour. When that happens the enum will grow exponentially and the naming will be disastrous as we must not change the existing enum name.
However, I don't really have strong opinion about this as I don't think it will should grow too much.
In regards for @chen-yumin multiple logical operator, I think you're thinking too much and trying to cover every bases.

As a user, if I touch a field then blur it without making any edit and don't see any error, I would assume there's actually nothing wrong with the field.
When you are trying to save, you can call validate() and it will show all the error immediately, which totally make sense.

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
If this was a simple true or false option, or a simple choice with 3 or 4 options, I'd definitely go with a flag, but given that the states we come up with are not just separable individual cases but they might need to be evaluated together with one another as a combined state, I don't see the benefit of having an enum flag over a custom function here. I wouldn't like having flags like ON_TOUCHED_OR_ON_SAVED, ON_BLUR_OR_ON_SAVED. Wouldn't touched || saved be cleaner? Using flags can be nicer when there are fewer options and when options are separate individuals, but in this case I'd find using a function more intuitive, cleaner and more customizable and flexible.
Anyway, I'll layout what the 2 different APIs might look like here and let you guys decide which one you'd prefer. I'm happy to change my PR and go forward with either way.



API
Using an Enum Flag
Using a Function




always
showError: ShowError.always
showErrorWhen:  (_) => true


touched
showError: ShowError.onTouched
showErrorWhen:  (field) => field.touched


blurred
showError: ShowError.onBlurred
showErrorWhen:  (field) => field.blurred


saved
showError: ShowError.onSaved
showErrorWhen:  (field) => field.saved


touched or saved
showError: ShowError.onTouchedOrSaved
showErrorWhen:  (field) => field.touched || field.saved


blurred or saved
showError: ShowError.onBlurredOrSaved
showErrorWhen:  (field) => field.blurred || field.saved


never
showError: ShowError.never
showErrorWhen:  (_) => false



Another thing I'd like to call out here, is the distinction between:

Stops the error from showing
Stops auto-validating (Stops calling the validate function automatically)

IMO, this feature is to stop the error from showing on the UI, but it does not stop the validate function from being called automatically when autovalidate: true is set. That's because we want to separate the UI error showing logic (whether errors should be shown to UI) from the validation logic (whether field is valid). The auto validation can keep the current FormField.hasError always up to date as an indicator of if the form is valid (using validator). This would also allow validate function being manually called without necessarily triggering the error to be shown, solving the problem that's raised in #48874.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
I tried coding up the three main validation strategies that I see, just to understand the problem better: https://dartpad.dartlang.org/9fb110c4dd1a910becb9bacd3422bdd5

Don't validate until the entire form is submitted.
Validate fields on blur (and validate the entire form when submitted).
Validate fields on focus and on change (and validate the entire form when submitted).

The only one that's currently easy to do with just parameters is number 1.  Number 2 requires some extra code in initState.  Number 3 requires extra code and extra state.
Well I definitely agree that Flutter is not making the most common use cases the easiest to build.  The interaction between autovalidate, .validate() and the showing of errors seems like it doesn't fit Flutter's declarative model as well as it could.  Any changes need to make the overall API simpler and not even more complex, though.

comments.author: SpajicM
justinmc
HansMuller
comments.bodyText:
Here's a slightly different proposal that I think addresses the use cases presented here.
Form and FormField get an onInteraction callback parameter with this signature:
void onInteraction({ FormFieldState field, bool shown, bool touched, bool focused, bool changed, bool saved })
The callback can call field.validate() if it wants to check the field's validity and show an error.
We'll run the callback:

When the field is first shown
When the field gains or loses the focus
The first time it's tapped after it gains the focus
Each time the value of the field changes
Each time the field is saved

Currently, all of the parameters correspond to "edge triggers" (only one parameter will be true at a time). I think this is preferable to an enum because it's a little more flexible:

Additional parameters can be added without risking breaking code that switches on an enum value.
We could add parameters that correspond to "level triggers" later, if that's really necessary.

This callback is intended as an alternative to autovalidate. The Form's onInteraction callback may not be used if autovalidate is true. A FormField's onInteraction callback may not be used if autovalidate is true.
Per #48948:
Add a FormFieldState.checkValid() method that returns the value of the FormField's validator callback. Returns null if there's no validator callback.

comments.author: tjonganthony
comments.bodyText:
I really like the idea that @HansMuller proposed. I think it will be able to cover most, if not all, cases that is covered here while not introducing new concept just for determining whether FormField should be showing error or not.
As per our chat also, we might be able to consider deprecating autovalidate and onChanged since this callback is a superset of both. Maybe we can leave that for another PR though :)

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
I like the idea as well! Looks like a good balance between ease of use and flexibility.
Your thoughts @chen-yumin ?

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
I like the onInteraction callback that @HansMuller proposed. But I have a couple of questions:

This callback is intended as an alternative to autovalidate. The Form's onInteraction callback may not be used if autovalidate is true. A FormField's onInteraction callback may not be used if autovalidate is true.

onInteraction sounds to be a usual event callback similar to onSaved or onChanged, so I'd expect it having similar behavior as well. It's not uncommon to see validate() being called in  onSaved or onChanged. Why should onInteraction be different and cannot be used with autovalidate? Should we put this restriction on the framework itself? People might come up with other use cases for onInteraction other than just validating errors. Is there a bit of an overlapping between onInteraction and other event callbacks? Would this confuse users into choosing onInteraction when they could otherwise just go for onChanged, for example?
Is this onInteraction per field, or would it make sense to add this callback to the Form as well? How would some of the attributes make sense if it's per form? For example: Would focused be attributed to any of its child fields having focus, and also pass that field as a parameter so you can validate() just for that field that has focus?
Both "validator" and "autovalidate" are available per form too. I think it'd be very useful to apply at a higher level -- per form, and even per app default. I was even thinking having this callback under MaterialApp so they can set their defaultErrorStateMatcher (or whatever you call it) globally for the whole app. Being able to set this globally IMO is more useful than per field for this feature. How can we solve for this with onInteraction?
Thoughts?

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
@chen-yumin The overlap crossed my mind as well.
On one hand, onChanged feels familiar, and intuitive, but if you think about it, changing the textbox implies the interaction with it. So it makes sense that being changed is a part onInteraction callback. Maybe we should deprecate it as @tjonganthony said.
About being per-field or per-form, my usecase is 100% per-form, but I think per-field should be added too, in case you have an exception, and need to override form-level behaviour for a single field.
So if onInteration is defined at form level, all it's fields should behave like you've put onInteraction on the field itself. If field has it's own onInteraction, then it should use that.
And about this rule being app-level - while it probably could be useful sometimes, I don't think we should go that far, the description of form behaviour should be kept 'close' to that form.

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText:
I'm not sure deprecating onChanged in favor of onInteraction is the right way forward. Event callbacks should be specific and relevant to the event they want to handle. onInteraction feels like an all-encompassing callback that handles all events without specificity. E.g. I'd want my onChanged and onBlur being separate callbacks instead of dumping them into a single big callback with a bunch of if-statements.
I'm also confused by what the bool flags in onInteration actually mean:

Are they supposed to be indicate what the event is (changed means it's an onChanged event, a subsequent save event will have changed to be false), or do they represent the sustained state since beginning (changed means the value has been changed and will not turn back to false until reset)?
The name onInteration gives me the impression that I can go if (changed) print("This is a onChanged event"), but it feels conflicting because I'm also under the impression that shown and focused represents a state that can be true regardless of what event it is.
If that only indicates the event type, then focused and shown will be false during an onChanged event, that'd be very confusing. And the users might have to again record the actual state using their own variables themselves. This defeats the whole purpose.
If they are just sustained states, how does the name onInteraction make sense, since you won't even know what is the interaction that triggered this? It's kind of like an all-encompassing onStateChange event without highlighting what's being changed.  Should we also pass all previous states so they'd know what's changed (e.g. if (prev.focused != new.focused) print("onFocusChange"))?  Even then, we cannot find out if it's an onChanged event because changed stays true for other events too.

Can those bool flags become getters on the FormFieldState? So you can use just field.hasFocus?
Also on a side note, we'd need separate variables to track focus gains (focused) and losses (blurred). Otherwise, we can't validate on blur. focused == false does not mean it's blurred. For error validation, I'm not interested in if it currently has focus, but whether it has ever gained focus, or has ever lost focus.

So if onInteration is defined at form level, all its fields should behave like you've put onInteraction on the field itself. If field has its own onInteraction, then it should use that.

Would it be helpful if we pass the FormState in onInteration as well? So you can access the form's state variables and call form.validate() or field.validate() depending on your need?

The description of form behaviour should be kept 'close' to that form.

I'd argue that this feature is close to a theme style. Same reason you'd want to avoid styling every single button individually. It's quite often that we need to apply the same errorStateMatcher on all forms and fields across the board. Maybe we should add this to ThemeData?  My understanding it is part of the visual theme to determine when to show error. -- ThemeData::errorStateMatcher

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
I'd argue that this feature is close to a theme style. Same reason you'd want to avoid styling every single button individually. It's quite often that we need to apply the same errorStateMatcher on all forms and fields across the board. Maybe we should add this to ThemeData? My understanding it is part of the visual theme to determine when to show error. -- ThemeData::errorStateMatcher

Theme is about defining visual styles - for example, the color and size of the error text under the field.
The logic of when that error appears should be somewhere else.
If you want to reuse onInteraction, put it in a VoidCallback or Function

comments.author: yumin-chen
comments.bodyText: How would you like the idea of an Inherited Widget FormAutoValidator that holds the validateOn callback? This would give you the freedom to define the scope it applies to -- wrap your entire app in it if you want to. And it does not introduce any API change to the current Form, or Field, though it is an alternative to autovalidate and aims to deprecate it.

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
Just a few points while we figure this out.

I think that the problems of applying validation behavior to all/multiple forms in an app should be solved using composition instead of theming or InheritedWidget.
For example, see my comment above where I wrote the code for a widget called FocusTextFormField.  By creating a wrapper on TextFormField, you can easily encapsulate and share your validation logic in a way that's more in-line with Flutter's way of doing things.

To clarify about the booleans as I understand it, they describe the current event and do not hold state about previous interactions.  For example, they don't tell you whether or not a field has ever been blurred in the past, and you would need to manage your own state if you need to know this.
@chen-yumin What's the specific pattern that you're trying to build that requires you to know previous interactions like this?  In another one of my comments above, I described the three main user experiences that I could think of off the top of my head in terms of when to show validation errors.  All three of them should be doable with Hans's proposal without maintaining additional state at least.

comments.author: SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
How would you like the idea of an Inherited Widget FormAutoValidator that holds the validateOn callback? This would give you the freedom to define the scope it applies to -- wrap your entire app in it if you want to. And it does not introduce any API change to the current Form, or Field, though it is an alternative to autovalidate and aims to deprecate it.

Not a fan of this idea - I'd like to be able to understand Form's behaviour by looking at the Form.
Imagine you continue working on someone else's code, and then you gotta hunt around the tree to see which FormAutoValidator widget affects your Form to see why it behaves the way it does.
If you wanna reuse the validation logic, I think Justin's or my earlier suggestion should be fine.
If you have that many Forms all across the app - maybe you should reconsider your UX :)
I still prefer @HansMuller solution, hopefully he can answer your earlier questions.

comments.author: yumin-chen
SpajicM
comments.bodyText:
It appears that we won't find a silver bullet here :(

This feature does not offer anything that can't already be done currently. The aim here is only to make it more convenient, with less verbose syntax, and get rid of more boilerplate code.

It aims to make the usual cases more easy - if you need something custom, like knowing the previous state, you'll have to write it yourself.

Having to define this attribute for every field / form adds another layer of verbosity, more boilerplate code.

In my opinion, it's not really boilerplate if it defines your functionality.
It's not the code everyone has to write to get the one same result (like for example setOnClickListeners in Android/Java)

I'm concerned that the onInteraction would become a rabbit hole jumble of logics, for the lack of a better expression

I agree it's not an ideal separation here, but I also think you pushed your example a bit too far for common use case. What your example shows is flexibility - but most commonly it's gonna be
if (saved || blurred || changed) {
    form.validate();
}
which doesn't look so bad to me.

comments.author: lzhuor
SpajicM
comments.bodyText: How to proceed on this?

comments.author: justinmc
comments.bodyText:
I'm going to close this PR as it seems like we're not coming to a consensus, but I agree there is a problem here that needs solving.  Let's continue the discussion on #18885 if anyone still has ideas.
I think the current best solution to this problem is to use composition to do the dirty work once and reuse it around the app.  I'm going to plan to revisit this and try to improve our existing messaging around how to do form validation.  I'll also be keeping an eye out for ways to improve the API.
Thanks to everyone that has chimed in on this and especially @chen-yumin for opening the PR.  This is the kind of great discussion that helps move open source projects like Flutter forward.

comments.author: yalva
justinmc
comments.bodyText:
I've published my example above as a pub package to try to make this stuff easier to do: easy_form_fields. You can just use EasyTextFormFieldFocus or EasyTextFormFieldUnfocus like a normal TextFormField, but it will validate on focus/unfocus.
Also, there are two PRs out right now seeking to make autovalidate not validate until an interaction has occurred: #56365 and #56132.  That should make the focus case more straightforward.  See the design doc if anyone has ideas.
