comments.author: abarth
comments.bodyText: Sorry.  requires sudo.

comments.author: pq
comments.bodyText: Yeah.  Unfortunate.  Now the question is whether there's any other alternative.  I'll do some more poking around.

comments.author: abarth
comments.bodyText: I'm not sure we want to require Trusty to use Flutter.  For example, requiring trusty prevents our customers from using a production Travis environment (Trusty support in Travis is in beta).  Our customers also lose support for Containers in Travis, which is recommend by Travis for reducing cycle times and unlocks several useful features in Travis that they use as carrots to get folks onto Containers.

comments.author: eseidelGoogle
comments.bodyText: Is this libc dependency change due to the borringssl role by chance? @zanderso

comments.author: abarth
comments.bodyText: There shouldn't be any connection between using C++11 features and which libc ABI you use.  For example, we use C++11 in sky_snapshot but it runs on old versions of Ubuntu.

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText: Yes, this is due to the BoringSSL roll. Our SDK builders are now using trusty.

comments.author: abarth
comments.bodyText: Looks like we build sky_snapshot on 14.04 but we're still able to run it on pre-trusty.

comments.author: whesse
comments.bodyText:
Dart can be built on earlier versions of linux, and/or with earlier glibc
versions.  The sdk we are building and releasing uses trusty because that
is the first release including a gcc with C++11.  It requires glibc 2.16
because the libc on trusty is 2.19, and the linker ends up using some 2.16
functions.
Anyone can build differently, using a sysroot or other Linux
distribution, and get the libc version requirement to 2.11 or less again.
Clank builds also solve the C++11 problem.
Since flutter does its own builds, I don't think it affects our
distribution of the prebuilt SDK built on trusty, does it?
The C++11 requirement does come from BoringSSL, but we may also start using
it in Dart VM code.
On Aug 9, 2016 04:15, "Adam Barth" notifications@github.com wrote:

Looks like we build sky_snapshot on 14.04 but we're still able to run it
on pre-trusty.
—

comments.author: a14n
comments.bodyText:
See travis-ci/travis-ci#6415
You can not use Trusty on container based jobs until travis-ci/travis-ci#5695 is fixed. Regarding https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/ci-environment#Virtualization-environments the main drawback of the current Trusty support is the boot time that will be larger (there's also an issue with content_shell but flutter doesn't matter).

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText: @whesse If we build the SDK on trusty using clang instead of gcc, would that also require the newer glibc?

comments.author: whesse
comments.bodyText:
Nothing requires the glibc, just if you compile using it (which is 2.19),
you get a linker requirement for 2.16 in the resulting executable.  You
need to specify a different glibc to link with, which I think is easiest
with a sysroot.  Or if you compile on precise, it only has 2.15, and you
end up with a executable requiring only 2.11.  So clang is only better
because clang works in precise, which has 2.15.
On Tue, Aug 9, 2016 at 4:46 PM, Zachary Anderson notifications@github.com
wrote:

@whesse https://github.com/whesse If we build the SDK on trusty using
clang instead of gcc, would that also require the newer glibc?

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText: Sorry, I was trying to ask if the clang we pull down uses the system sysroot, or its own sysroot. That is, would a binary built with the clang we pull down also ask for glibc 2.16.

comments.author: whesse
comments.bodyText:
Probably.  Run ldd -v dart
on the dart executable, and it shows the libc version requirements.
The CLANG settiings, which should be all you need, are
CC: third_party/clang/linux/bin/clang
CC_host: third_party/clang/linux/bin/clang
CHROME_HEADLESS: 1
CPLUS_INCLUDE_PATH: third_party/clang/linux/lib/clang/3.4/include/
CXX: third_party/clang/linux/bin/clang++ -fsanitize=address -fPIC
CXX_host: third_party/clang/linux/bin/clang++
C_INCLUDE_PATH: third_party/clang/linux/lib/clang/3.4/include/
On Tue, Aug 9, 2016 at 5:04 PM, Zachary Anderson notifications@github.com

comments.author: abarth
comments.bodyText:
Since flutter does its own builds, I don't think it affects our distribution of the prebuilt SDK built on trusty, does it?

Flutter uses the dart-sdk distributed by the Dart team in our end-developer workflow.  We use it to execute Dart code on the host system (e.g., the flutter command line tool and pub).  If we upgrade to this version of the dart-sdk, our end-developers will no longer be able to use older versions of Ubuntu.

comments.author: whesse
comments.bodyText:
We can change our builders to build a dart sdk that doesn't require glibc
2.16.  I've had the contingency plan that we can change our SDK builders to
use a sysroot, and compile against an earlier glibc, if major customers
required it.  It sounds like that is what you (and perhaps other customers)
want, so I'll plan to make this change tomorrow, and get out a new dev
version 1.19.0-dev.5.0 that should work for you.  I'll send out an email to
dart-core-dev proposing that.
On Tue, Aug 9, 2016 at 5:52 PM, Adam Barth notifications@github.com wrote:

Since flutter does its own builds, I don't think it affects our
distribution of the prebuilt SDK built on trusty, does it?
Flutter uses the dart-sdk distributed by the Dart team in our
end-developer workflow. We use it to execute Dart code on the host system
(e.g., the flutter command line tool and pub). If we upgrade to this
version of the dart-sdk, our end-developers will no longer be able to use
older versions of Ubuntu.

comments.author: AesSedai101
comments.bodyText:
If you have your add to app project depending on another plugin with a native dependency (in your case, flutterboost depending on shared_preferences) via the pubspec, the dependencies in the POM uses the new classifier mechanism.
For example., in my main add to app module, I use logging_to_logcat, which gets included like this:
   <dependency>
      <groupId>com.logger.logging_to_logcat</groupId>
      <artifactId>logging_to_logcat</artifactId>
      <version>1.0.0</version>
      <scope>compile</scope>
    </dependency>

with the -debug and -release classifiers mapping to the flavours.
so, if you don't publish the artifacts in the new way with the classifiers, you will need to declare all Flutter dependencies with a native component manually in the gradle file of your native project.

comments.author: JunhuaLin
comments.bodyText:
If you have your add to app project depending on another plugin with a native dependency (in your case, flutterboost depending on shared_preferences) via the pubspec, the dependencies in the POM uses the new classifier mechanism.
For example., in my main add to app module, I use logging_to_logcat, which gets included like this:
   <dependency>
      <groupId>com.logger.logging_to_logcat</groupId>
      <artifactId>logging_to_logcat</artifactId>
      <version>1.0.0</version>
      <scope>compile</scope>
    </dependency>

with the -debug and -release classifiers mapping to the flavours.
so, if you don't publish the artifacts in the new way with the classifiers, you will need to declare all Flutter dependencies with a native component manually in the gradle file of your native project.

name: flutter_boost
description: A next-generation Flutter-Native hybrid solution. FlutterBoost is a Flutter plugin which enables hybrid integration of Flutter for your existing native apps with minimum efforts.
version: 3.0.0

homepage: https://github.com/alibaba/flutter_boost

environment:

dependencies:

    sdk: flutter
  collection: ^1.16.0
  logging_to_logcat: ^0.1.1               <---- plugin

dev_dependencies:
  flutter_lints: ^2.0.1
  flutter_test:
    sdk: flutter
  pigeon: ^3.2.9

flutter:

      android:

        pluginClass: FlutterBoostPlugin
      ios:

flutterboost  gradle file:
group 'com.idlefish.flutterboost'
version '1.0-SNAPSHOT'

buildscript {
    repositories {
        google()
        jcenter()
    }

    dependencies {
        classpath 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:7.0.4'
    }
}

rootProject.allprojects {
    repositories {
        google()
        jcenter()
    }
}

apply plugin: 'com.android.library'

android {
    compileSdkVersion 31
    buildToolsVersion '30.0.2'
    defaultConfig {
        minSdkVersion 16
        targetSdkVersion 31
        testInstrumentationRunner 'androidx.test.runner.AndroidJUnitRunner'
    }
    lintOptions {
        disable 'InvalidPackage'
        abortOnError false
    }

    compileOptions {
        sourceCompatibility JavaVersion.VERSION_1_8
        targetCompatibility JavaVersion.VERSION_1_8
    }
}

dependencies {

    implementation 'com.squareup.okhttp3:okhttp:3.5.0'                  <------ native
}

ext {

    artifactId = "FlutterBoost"
}

author: Jonah Williams

comments.author: flar
comments.bodyText: I agree that we only want the forced compositing and isolated children on animating things. Some apps might drive opacity animations directly themselves using an Opacity widget, but they should look to use an animated widget instead for multiple reasons (for one thing, fewer rebuilds of their tree).

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
I agree that we only want the forced compositing and isolated children on animating things. Some apps might drive opacity animations directly themselves using an Opacity widget, but they should look to use an animated widget instead for multiple reasons (for one thing, fewer rebuilds of their tree).

Agreed. The docs already push people strongly away from Opacity if they want to animate.

The animations produce a double, though. I'm leaning toward breaking change depending on how wide your search was.

comments.bodyText:
The OpacityLayer also takes an alpha: 
  
    
      flutter/packages/flutter/lib/src/rendering/layer.dart
    
    
         Line 1751
      in
      fba9214
    
  
  
    

        
          
           set alpha(int? value) { 
        
    
  


I can certainly do the breaking change. We have a lot of headroom before the next release

comments.author: flar
comments.bodyText:
The OpacityLayer also takes an alpha:

  
    
      flutter/packages/flutter/lib/src/rendering/layer.dart
    
    
         Line 1751
      in
      fba9214
    
  
  
    

        
          
           set alpha(int? value) { 
        
    
  


I can certainly do the breaking change. We have a lot of headroom before the next release

We can and should fix that. The graphics libraries can take double, so we shouldn't restrict the higher level interfaces to a lower precision (though in practice, the final results are an 8-bit pixel component, there are calculations before you get there that can happen in floating point and carry more precision until the final round to store the value in the framebuffer).
Also, it could take both types of value with a comment/assert to use only one of them.

comments.author: flar
comments.bodyText:
It looks like phones are already embracing 10-bit per component technology.
https://ledstrain.org/d/1358-phones-with-true-10-bit-display

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: If we can make the engine accept a double, we can certainly always provide a double. We won't always get to take advantage of the extra resolution though, since the Color class can only store an alpha, and the Paint object only accepts a color.

comments.author: flar
comments.bodyText:
If we can make the engine accept a double, we can certainly always provide a double. We won't always get to take advantage of the extra resolution though, since the Color class can only store an alpha, and the Paint object only accepts a color.

We can have the ui.Paint object accept an alpha or an opacity on top of the color.
Can we expand the ui.Color class to store higher precision in a backward compatible way? Skia has Color and something like Color4f and the SkPaint takes an alpha(int) or an alphaf(SkScalar).
Stuff we're going to have to consider at some point, but we can start with making new APIs take doubles, and can even have them take an int? or double? for both options.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Makes sense, will update. I do sort of wonder if we should also use a small epsilon for comparison too...

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: RE: colors and opacity, we can definitely add new color objects/paint types. It would be good to evaluate what we need to move towards in the next few years so we can coordinate all the required changes

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
Filled a bug for us to discuss next week: #102888
I had a thought that this might be something we can use dart fix with.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: Since I looked again and found no use of these APIs outside of the flutter code base, I'm thinking we should just do the breaking change

In my last comment, I wrote "it would be nice to add another one that confirms the styling logic you've written is behaving as anticipated", which I now realize was a little unclear. The key function I would like to see tested is _labelStyle, since it accepts an index and merges that with the user's progress through the stepper and the Dark Mode / Light Mode status before ultimately yielding a TextStyle. The internals of that function are pretty complicated, so I think we should have tests to verify that a Stepper with X steps, and currently at step Y, is rendering each label correctly. There are a few scenarios to cover there - steps before, on, and after the active step; in both light mode and dark mode.
Does all of that make sense?
PS - I promise not to disappear this time!

comments.author: filiph
comments.bodyText:
One complication that I only realized as I'm testing locally is the fact that adding generated localization from the very start invalidates our flutter create steps.
Observe:
$ flutter create -t skeleton my_test
Creating project my_test...
  [...]
Wrote 133 files.

All done!
In order to run your application, type:

  $ cd my_test
  $ flutter run

Your application code is in my_test/lib/main.dart.

If you try to follow the instructions above, you get an error:
$ cd my_test
$ flutter run
Launching lib/main.dart on Pixel 2 XL in debug mode...
Error: Couldn't resolve the package 'flutter_gen' in 'package:flutter_gen/gen_l10n/app_localizations.dart'.
lib/src/app.dart:2:8: Error: Not found: 'package:flutter_gen/gen_l10n/app_localizations.dart'
import 'package:flutter_gen/gen_l10n/app_localizations.dart';
       ^
[...]

Exception: Gradle task assembleDebug failed with exit code 1

What you need to do at that point is:
$ flutter pub get

After that, flutter run works. This is confusing, since some version of flutter pub get is called after flutter create, as far as I know. I guess it's running too soon?
@jonahwilliams and I quickly chatted about this on Discord because the same issue happens in testing. It's easy enough to run flutter pub get --offline in automated tests, but it's harder to ask users to remember to do that.
Now, I wonder if we want to fix the flutter create output (easier but uglier) or to start automatically doing flutter pub get --offline after create.
We never had this issue because no template had source generation in it from the very beginning.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
Now, I wonder if we want to fix the flutter create output (easier but uglier) or to start automatically doing flutter pub get --offline after create.

I think this sounds like a reasonable approach, it will be fast and we could always hide the output from that step too.

Looking at the benchmarks, it's not clear that this had the impact we were hoping for.
I didn't see any change on memory-related benchmarks I looked at, or on performance macrobenchmarks.
On the listener-specific microbenchmarks, on Android it made addListener2_iteration much (~10x) worse (maybe because it pushed the benchmark into needing more GC?), addListener3_iteration, addListener4_iteration, and addListener5_iteration a little worse (~15%), the notifyListenerX_iteration benchmarks got better (higher Xs got proportionally better improvement), and removeListenerX_iteration tests are mostly unaffected. On iOS the data is too noisy to discern an effect, though based on eyeballing the data, I suspect that if we were to do a rigorous analysis we'd find similar trends but with less amplitude.
Overall I think this was a wash. :-/ Probably worth keeping since hopefully adding listeners is rarer than notifying, though there's a chance this will have a negative effect on launch performance.

comments.author: Kavantix
liyuqian
comments.bodyText:
Traversal over a continuous range of elements is expected to be much slower for a LinkedList compared to a List for the following reasons.

A List puts adjacent items in adjacent memory. When you access a list item, the CPU L1/L2 cache will fetch adjacent memory which likely covers the next few items. Hence visiting the next item will be a CPU L1/L2 cache hit which is much faster than accessing the main memory.
A LinkedList puts adjacent item in random locations. Accessing an item is unlikely to fetch adjacent items into CPU L1/L2 cache. Hence visiting adjacent items will be slower due to cache miss, but it has a better asymptotic complexity when items can be inserted/removed at random locations. A List takes O(N) time to do that while a LinkedList takes O(1) time to do that.

Of course, one can implement a custom HybridList which links smaller continuous List together to utilize CPU L1/L2 cache for adjacent items, and limit worst case complexity by limiting the smaller List to have a constant size.
That may be an over-optimization unless we can prove that piece of code is actually a bottleneck in real applications. That said, I'm Ok with both the List and LinkedList approach since I haven't seen any related performance issues in real applications yet. Even the O(N^2) vs O(N) worst case complexity doesn't bother me too much as I expect N to be quite small (<10) in most cases. For example, the standard quick sort algorithm in C++ uses O(N^2) sorting algorithm instead of O(N log N) algorithm for small N.
In summary, if it's me, I'll just pick the one that's easiest to implement and read, until I see a performance issue in a real app.

To get timestamp, not diff content, right?. Is this number significantly different between windows and mac or linux?

Right, no actual content is read and no File_open calls show up for this portion in the CPU profile. The execution time for the flutter_gallery is about ~90ms for mac/linux which is faster, but still significant.

What is the file watcher's latency? Is there a concern that flutter tools won't get notified in time if hot reload follows file update? IJ flutter plugin has a mode where it does automatic hot reload on every save.

I didn't notice any issues when testing locally using hot reload on save, I tested on Linux, Mac, and Windows. There was one place where I encountered an issue, the hot reload integration test which mutates a file and then calls hot reload: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/28152/files#diff-ce4fde68d0bd16865c11a354197704dcR42.
Currently if a file were to be missed then it could be picked up on the next hot reload.

comments.author: zanderso
comments.bodyText:
Currently if a file were to be missed then it could be picked up on the next hot reload.

I think it's not that simple. For example, consider:

The IDE saves many files all at once.
The IDE issues a hot reload
(These both percolate through the Dart VM's IO eventhandler in non-deterministic order)
The flutter tool receives the hot reload command before receiving every file system watcher event
Hot reload fails because of failing to read updates for files whose events haven't come in yet.

Any workaround that adds delays or re-queueing messages will eventually get bitten by this race.
One fix could be to supply some sort of ACK to the IDE so that the IDE doesn't issue the hot reload command until getting an ACK for each file that it has saved recently.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
One fix could be to supply some sort of ACK to the IDE so that the IDE doesn't issue the hot reload command until getting an ACK for each file that it has saved recently.

We could also have the daemon protocol provide the list of changed files itself. So in this case, save multiple files and hot reload, the updated files are sent along with the daemon request? We can leave the watchers for non-daemon workflows or editors which don't support that portion.
cc @devoncarew

comments.author: devoncarew
comments.bodyText:
I agree w/ the race condition logic in #28152 (comment).
Is it feasible to re-scan the filesystem for changes when flutter_tools receives a reload/restart request? By the time the IDEs send that request, they've already saved any dirty files.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
Adding some numbers so that we're aware of the context here:
VSCode:
FileWatch notification: 1551824700858
Hot Reload started: 1551824701059
About 200 ms of latency
Intellij:
FileWatch notification: 1551825011092
Hot Reload started: 1551825011202
About 110 ms of latency

Is it feasible to re-scan the filesystem for changes when flutter_tools receives a reload/restart request?

We can, the problem is that it is slow, especially on windows. A single library invalidation hot reload on a windows emulators with this change takes 180 ms. Scanning the flutter gallery and dependencies (a fairly small application) takes about 170 ms, or about as much time as the hot reload itself.

Hot reload fails because of failing to read updates for files whose events haven't come in yet.

I haven't been able to reproduce a case where this error is triggered. I am not sure if the frontend server can allow it.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText:
I think I have an idea to drive this forward.

We re-instate file stat for diffing the workspace and packages

We always skip file stat on packages in the pub-cache. Updating a package means changing the directory and the pub cache is shared across all apps, so changing the files there is unsafe.
That should still improve performance somewhat, since a noticeable chunk of the file stat was in the dependencies.

For build_runner based workflows with code generation, we augment the daemon protocol to also return a list of additional files produced during the build. This would allow us to skip file stat in the .dart_tool build cache, which could potentially contain thousands of stale or intermediary artifacts.

@zanderso @aam WDUT?

comments.author: aam
comments.bodyText:
We always skip file stat on packages in the pub-cache. Updating a package means changing the directory and the pub cache is shared across all apps, so changing the files there is unsafe.

What about the case when you do pub upgrade(independently from ongoing debugging session) which updates pub-cache contents? You do want for hot reload compiler to pick up updated packages in that case, do you?

comments.author: aam
comments.bodyText:
Ah, I guess pub upgrade won't update existing versions of the packages, can only download new ones.
I know me myself in the past have been editing sources in pubcache location - sometimes that is very convenient quick way to experiment with changes in some packages.

comments.author: jonahwilliams
comments.bodyText: It is definitely something I have done as well, but I think supporting it with hot reload is an edge case. pub itself also has no idea that you might have changed something in the cache, so the modified files are left around until that directory is manually deleted or reverted.

comments.author: DanTup
comments.bodyText:
Ok, got it:
dantup-macbookpro:inetutils-1.9 dantup$ flutter emulators --start danny
dantup-macbookpro:inetutils-1.9 dantup$ adb devices
List of devices attached
emulator-5554	device

dantup-macbookpro:inetutils-1.9 dantup$ telnet/telnet localhost 5554
Connected to localhost.
Escape character is '^]'.
Android Console: Authentication required
Android Console: type 'auth <auth_token>' to authenticate
Android Console: you can find your <auth_token> in 
'/Users/dantup/.emulator_console_auth_token'
OK
avd name

OK

I can't find a way to get this through adb shell, seems to be a special command that works over telnet. So I think whenever flutter devices polls, we will need to open a telnet connection, run avd name and then close the connection. I don't know how much more expensive this'll make it but it'll mean we could subtract these names from the list of AVDs and then add what's left to the end of the devices list and allow a user to launch them.

comments.author: DanTup
comments.bodyText:
@devoncarew @mit-mit
I created a branch of this code and implemented showing the AVD name in flutter devices (I don't think we want this, it was just an easy place to put it to show it's working so we can review the Code to see whether we want to be connecting to devices like this):
DanTup@5cab59c

Danny_Nexus is the AVD name for this emulator.
With this, we could extend flutter devices to fetch the list of AVDs (as we currently have in emulators), remove those where a running device has that AVD name and then show those items on the end of the list as offline.
It does mean making the devices command/classes more complicated and blurs these emulator images with devices; however to the end user this might make more sense.
LMK what you think, or we can discuss next week if easier on VC.

comments.author: devoncarew
comments.bodyText:
Taking a look at this again (and, sorry for the long delay!).
I have two comments on the UX, and will take a spin through the code after:
I'd like to keep lists of emulators out of the output of flutter devices. I don't have any super defensible reasons for this, but like the separation. Instead, if no devices are found in flutter devices, we should change our ending message in flutter devices from:
If you expected your device to be detected, please run "flutter doctor" to diagnose
potential issues, or visit https://flutter.io/setup/ for troubleshooting tips.

to something like:
Run 'flutter emulators' to list and start any available device emulators.

Or, if you expected a device to be detected, run "flutter doctor" to diagnose
potential issues or visit https://flutter.io/setup/ for troubleshooting tips.

The other UI think is that we could consider a different name for --start; perhaps --launch? --run might be conflated with actually starting an app.

comments.author: DanTup
comments.bodyText:
@devoncarew

can you clarify re: 'Issues with awaiting the launch of emulator' - I didn't find the reference in the PR

Currently emulator.dart declares launch as returning void, but the overrides return Futures. If we change it to Future and then await it, then flutter emulators --launch x will await the completion of that process (wait until the user closes it).
If I don't await the process in the launch method, then I can't check the exit code. So, I guess I need to wait a short period (a second?) and if the process is still running, then assume it's a running emulator and not wait for it (we want to return the user to a terminal). I can't just fire-and-forget from the start because if it fails we'll give the user no indication of what it didn't launch (eg. not route the stderr to them).

comments.author: DanTup
devoncarew
comments.bodyText:
If I don't await the process in the launch method, then I can't check the exit code. So, I guess I need to wait a short period (a second?) and if the process is still running, then assume it's a running emulator and not wait for it (we want to return the user to a terminal). I can't just fire-and-forget from the start because if it fails we'll give the user no indication of what it didn't launch (eg. not route the stderr to them).

Ah, gotcha. There's no signal to indicate a successful launch.

Should we support flutter-tester here?

I'm not sure it helps, but haven't thought about it.
lgtm w/ the logic to check for an unsuccessful launch (that takes a few seconds to determine).

comments.author: DanTup
comments.bodyText:
I'm not sure it helps, but haven't thought about it.

I was thinking if flutter-tester was listed and launchable, it might give us a way to have some tests that don't don't can run outside of devicelab and don't require some specific setup on devicelab. However, it occurs to me now that flutter devices includes the test device when passed the flag always; it doesn't list it only when it's running (since it doesn't really run like a normal device that can be connected to).
Anyway, I've pushed a change to add the missing awaits and to automatically return from AndroidEmulator.launch() after 3 seconds if the process is still running.
There are two outstanding issues at the top; one is about Simulator location - I think we should probably just remove the TODO and assume the path is always this. If it's not, the worst to happen is that the simulator won't appear in the devices list.
The other one is about tests. I think the options are:

Leave them until we've done --create and then create devicelab tests that create, list, launch, verify launch
Ensure devicelab has some consistent AVDs (and iOS Simulator?) we can use

If we're going to do 1, it'd be good to have someone else check the code out and have a little test for sanity. LMK what you think!

title: [defunct] MediaQuery as InheritedModel
author: Callum Moffat

comments.author: skia-gold
comments.bodyText:
Gold has detected about 1 new digest(s) on patchset 2.
View them at https://flutter-gold.skia.org/cl/github/97928

comments.author: b3nni97
comments.bodyText: Is this still being worked on?

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText: I think I need to make an issue so that it will be reviewed. Will do that.

comments.author: nikitadol
comments.bodyText:
I propose a more universal solution:
Add a function select (which will be caught by InheritedWidget or InheritedModel), as was done in the package provider
https://github.com/rrousselGit/provider/blob/master/lib/src/inherited_provider.dart#L246
Since it will be useful not only for MediaQuery

comments.author: b3nni97
comments.bodyText: Can anyone here review the PR? This improves the performance of many apps.

comments.author: FelixMittermeier
comments.bodyText:
This looks very promising 👍🏻 Thanks for your work.
These kind of performance improvements are always great

comments.author: aurangzaibsiddiqui
comments.bodyText:
Hi,
This can be very useful for my application as I am facing a lot of jank on soft keyboard pop-up. However, I am relatively new to Flutter programming. Can someone please guide me how I can use @moffatman's solution?
As in how do I pull his github into my Flutter code?

comments.author: b3nni97
comments.bodyText: Can anyone here review this? This is not a breaking change and for all who modify their code a lot of unnecessary rebuilds will be avoided... @Piinks

comments.author: marctan
comments.bodyText: any update on this? still not in stable?

comments.author: goderbauer
moffatman
comments.bodyText:
I have never added a new lint, is it hard to do that? Something like use_build_context_synchronously. I can't think of any valid cases where you want to grab the whole MediaQuery object but only rebuild when certain things change, which couldn't be solved by just using MediaQuery::of with different aspects where needed.
I guess for a completely "safe" API, this should be scrapped and replaced with MediaQuery.sizeOf(context) type methods for each aspect.

comments.author: rotorgames
nikitadol
comments.bodyText:
I propose a more universal solution:
Add a function select (which will be caught by InheritedWidget or InheritedModel), as was done in the package provider
https://github.com/rrousselGit/provider/blob/master/lib/src/inherited_provider.dart#L246
Since it will be useful not only for MediaQuery

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
I guess for a completely "safe" API, this should be scrapped and replaced with MediaQuery.sizeOf(context) type methods for each aspect.

That sounds like a better approach.

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText:
@goderbauer
I have a version locally now where it works like that, but I have an issue. We already had textScaleFactorOf and a few others, which actually return default values instead of throwing an error if there is no MediaQuery ancestor.
Do you think it's better to:

Follow the same convention on the new methods

For example, MediaQuery.paddingOf(context) will return EdgeInsets.zero if there is no MediaQuery ancestor


Have a mix of behaviors

MediaQuery.paddingOf(context) will throw if there isn't a MediaQuery ancestor, but MediaQuery.textScaleFactorOf(context) will return 1.0


Break the old behaviors

Everything throws if no MediaQuery ancestor. Use maybeOf to be safe, it will break anyone who has no MediaQuery ancestor, but I'm not sure who that affects.

comments.author: zhangwen0510
comments.bodyText: any update on this?

comments.author: zhangwen0510
comments.bodyText: @goderbauer

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText: FWIW, I think returning defaults for these makes sense, but @goderbauer would know better how well that fits with existing framework API

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText: (And this would also help fix a performance issue on mobile where offscreen routes are getting rebuilt unnecessarily when the IME is involved)

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: I think having a mix of behaviors like you have implemented is fine. If we have a resonable default value, the of method can and should return it. If we don't it throws. And you can always use maybeOf if you want to know whether there is an ancestor or not.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: Maybe we should combine this with a lint to avoid MediaQuery.of and steer people towards the more specific getters?

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText: Lots of cases of inline documentation and on the website I should also update to point to these optimized methods.

comments.author: nikitadol
comments.bodyText:
Hi
Why don't you want to make 1 universal solution for the InheritedWidget?

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText:
Hi Why don't you want to make 1 universal solution for the InheritedWidget?

Mainly laziness 😁, in this way I am just using the already existing InheritedModel. I use and like provider and select myself, I just thought it would be a lot more work to copy that feature into the flutter framework. But feel free to go ahead and propose a PR if it's not as hard as I thought.

comments.author: nikitadol
comments.bodyText:
Hi Why don't you want to make 1 universal solution for the InheritedWidget?

Mainly laziness 😁, in this way I am just using the already existing InheritedModel. I use and like provider and select myself, I just thought it would be a lot more work to copy that feature into the flutter framework. But feel free to go ahead and propose a PR if it's not as hard as I thought.

By making this PR, it will only solve part of the problems, since MediaQuery is a small part that uses InheritedWidget
I understand that other solutions (for example, the implementation of select) will take a lot of time, but no one has agreed or denied that such a solution could exist

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText:
I thought of some default values here. But the more I think about it, I would rather not add new default values, and just keep the minimum compatibility the old behaviour. I don't see the value of hiding this likely accidental state where there is no MediaQuery ancestor.

Notes

WidgetsBinding.instance.window.physicalSize



orientation
Could be imputed from size

1.0

🟢 Existing behaviour

🟢 Existing behaviour

EdgeInsets.zero

EdgeInsets.zero



systemGestureInsets
EdgeInsets.zero



viewPadding
EdgeInsets.zero



alwaysUse24HourFormat
false



accessibleNavigation
false



invertColors
false



highContrast
false
🟢 Existing behaviour


disableAnimations
false



boldTextOverride
false
🟠 There is already MediaQuery.boldTextOverride (notice no of in the name), which has a default return value of false.Would like to deprecate that one and rename to match as MediaQuery.boldTextOverrideOf.Not sure if it's accepted to deprecated and rename just to match other names?


navigationMode
NavigationMode.traditional



gestureSettings
const DeviceGestureSettings()



displayFeatures
const []

comments.bodyText:
I would rather not add new default values, and just keep the minimum compatibility the old behaviour.

I agree with this.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText: @moffatman Sorry for the hassle, but could you close this PR and open a new one with the same change? It looks like since this PR is so old our golden testing infra got confused by it and is in a corrupted state. Opening this as a new PR should resolve the issue.

comments.author: cbracken
comments.bodyText:
Thans for your patience. I'm currently doing some design work on PlatformViews for macOS. As part of that, one of the things I'm investigating is whether we can find a way to come up with a more general approach to PlatformView support in the framework that avoids adding platform-specific API like UiKitView etc.
This is problematic because these classes are tied to specific embedders, which makes them somewhat meaningless on other embedders, and forces custom embedder authors to maintain their own fork of the framework if they want to enable PlatformViews for their embedding.
Ideally, I'd like it if we could get to the point where the framework exposes a set of basic classes that aren't platform-specific and the platform-specific bits could be done in a cleaner more pluggable way. I'm still evaluating the feasibility of this approach. Until then I'd like to hold off on adding more platform-specific cases to the framework.
I think it's reasonable to keep this open while I dig into the macOS side and get back here.

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
I think it's reasonable to keep this open while I dig into the macOS side and get back here.

(Triage) @cbracken should this still be open?

comments.author: cbracken
comments.bodyText:
I'm going to close this for the time being, in order to get it off the review queue until we've worked out the right approach to consolidating the API in a way that works for all platforms. That's a problem being actively hacked out right now on macOS and Windows/Linux are on our agenda next. I do think that some of the consolidation work in this framework PR is something we want to followup on though.
Once we're set with macOS, we will absolutely want to get back to landing platform views for Linux.

title: Add `allowedButtonsFilter` to prevent Draggable from appearing with secondary click.
author: Bernardo Ferrari

comments.author: a-wallen
comments.bodyText:
👋  @bernaferrari thanks for the contribution. I'm going to try my best to help get this one across the finish line. I think that we definitely want this PR, but we also want to do it the right way. I'm going to break up my feedback into 3 parts.

Revisions regarding changes to the API design.
Revisions regarding the functionality of the code.
Revisions regarding the readability of the code.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: Sorry, I thought this would be my simplest PR in a while. I didn't expect that much complexity. After talking with the other reviewer (I won't tag, so he isn't notified), he gave the idea to modify MultiDragGestureRecognizer and I like the idea. Just committed. I'm not changing the precious GestureRecognizer (yet, but I could).

comments.author: HansMuller
comments.bodyText: It would be good to apply this change to all of the components where it's warranted, not just Draggable. Like scrollbar thumbs, slider thumbs, tab dragging, there are probably others.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
@HansMuller right now I'm changing MultiGestureRecognizer (less destructive). I can change GestureRegognizer (used everywhere) to disallow right click by default. There is even a kind-of TODO comment there. The question, I guess, is...
Is this the right PR to make that change? Do we want to be super impactful here? The reviewer gave the idea to fix this first, then fix the others (if needed), but I can just put a default parameter in GestureRecognizer and it would change everywhere.

comments.author: moffatman
comments.bodyText: I thought it wouldn't apply to all GestureRecognizer subclasses, since some have specific handling and separated callbacks for different buttons already. And it looks like the single-drag recognizers that are more commonly used (HorizontalDragGestureRecognizer etc) already only allow drags with the primary button.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Here is what Flutter does.
DragGestureRecognizer (slider) is currently locked to primary button. MultiDragGestureRecognizer doesn't lock to anything (this proposal).
MultiTapGestureRecognizer, ForcePressGestureRecognizer and ScaleGestureRecognizer could have unexpected behaviors since they don't check for primary button. Someone said it is possible to have right click on iPad with touch.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
I renamed it again, and fixed the tests. If/after this lands, we could update DragGestureRecognizer (sliders) to do the same, so they would share a similar API.
This is my plan:

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: cc @moffatman after many many many comments and changes, now is your time to review! 🎉

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
I agree buttons is not clear, but everybody is struggling to find a better name (specially since the internal methods use buttons and the user will need bit-wise operations for some more advanced scenarios).
The callback is int buttons right now. Could be PointerEvent pointer. We are one step from just transforming isPointerAllowed into a builder.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: Testing a new name: ButtonsEventFilter buttonsEventFilter. The review comments are fixed, and documentation is improved.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: Friendly ping @Piinks. How do you feel about the updated naming (buttonsEventFilter)?

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
There has been a lot of really great collaboration on this PR, although I feel that it is not super clear the best way to proceed. Everyone's input is super valid, and I think it is important to still consider the framework at large and having a consistent pattern that works across multiple use cases before we commit to one.
@Renzo-Olivares has been working in this area as well, maybe he has some suggestions on how we can approach this thinking about framework mouse gestures as a whole, and not just one subset.

comments.author: Renzo-Olivares
comments.bodyText: I'm also still unsure about the name. What do you think about supportedButtonsFilter? or would that be confusing with supportedDevices? Maybe allowedButtonsFilter? buttonsEventFilter seems a little confusing to me, it sounds like there is some ButtonEvent we are referring to but we are referring to PointerEvent.buttons.

comments.author: a-wallen
comments.bodyText:
GestureRecognizer buttonsEventFilter API support project ☔

Add buttonsEventFilter support to DoubleTapGestureRecognizer

@bernaferrari feel free to chime in and let us know what you think.

comments.author: Piinks
comments.bodyText:
I agree with @Renzo-Olivares & @a-wallen regarding making this consistent across all of those classes. I think I raised this point earlier as well.
That would only involve piping it through as a super parameter to all of the subclasses like we did in #81858
Adding parameters to classes ad hoc creates inconsistencies in the framework. While the request is for support in this particular widget, how it relates to other widgets in the framework should be accounted for. This is embracing the yak shave. :)

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText: Could you check what's failing in Google testing and if it's a big deal? Else the bigger change might trigger more things.

comments.author: goderbauer
comments.bodyText:
Could you check what's failing in Google testing and if it's a big deal? Else the bigger change might trigger more things.

You'll have to rebase this PR to the latest master to kick off another "google testing" run. Can you please do that?

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
Hey! Sorry for the end of the year delay! 😅 Tests are ok now.
So, I just did what you asked me to. I added super.allowedButtonsFilter everywhere. This creates a few "inconsistencies", but so far so good.
For example, LongPressGestureRecognizer independently tracks primary/secundary/tertiary buttons. Theoretically, allowedButtonsFilter could handle that, and allow for more complex customization, but these are sent as callback (such as onSecondaryLongPressDown). So unless we convert the 3 variations of each into a single and expose to the user (like onLongPressDown(int mouseButtons)), I don't think it would work. Given it is used in Editable, it is unrealistic to expect different longPress configurations. I think it is fine the way it currently is.

✅ DragGestureRecognizer: I replaced where it tracked kPrimaryButton with support for anything. So now it is more versatile than ever.

Easy ones:

 Add buttonsEventFilter support to GestureRecognizer
  Add buttonsEventFilter support to OneSequenceGestureRecognizer
  Add buttonsEventFilter support to ScaleGestureRecognizer
  Add buttonsEventFilter support to EagerGestureRecognizer
 Add buttonsEventFilter support to SerialTapGestureRecognizer
 Add buttonsEventFilter support to PanGestureRecognizer
 Add buttonsEventFilter support to MultiTapGestureRecognizer
 Add buttonsEventFilter support to PrimaryPointerGestureRecognizer
  Add buttonsEventFilter support to BaseTapGestureRecognizer

Refactors:

 Add buttonsEventFilter support to DragGestureRecognizer | HorizontalDragGestureRecognizer | VerticalDragGestureRecognizer

Harder ones:

 Add buttonsEventFilter support to LongPressGestureRecognizer
 Add buttonsEventFilter support to TapGestureRecognizer

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
What should I do with DoubleTapGestureRecognizer? It is primary button only right now.
Should we do anything with LongPressGestureRecognizer? I don't think so.

I changed the default allowedButtonsFilter to allow all, and on DragGestureRecognizer (slider) and MultiDragGestureRecognizer (drag and drop) I made the default kPrimaryButton only.

comments.author: bernaferrari
comments.bodyText:
DoubleTapGestureRecognizer is going to call super.isPointerAllowed(event) which triggers the change we are making. By default it accept all, so no changes. But you can do weird things, because allowedButtonsFilter can block different buttons, so, by default primary -> secondary -> primary, not a double tap because there was a middle tap of different button. Now, if the user changes allowedButtonFilter, primary -> secondary (ignored) -> primary -> double tap is a success.
We could further relax DoubleTapGestureRecognizer, like here. But I think it is ok in its current situation:

Regarding LongPressGestureRecognizer,
a) by default it accepts a single button, and it only really works if a callback is enabled. So the only thing allowedButtonsFilter could do is make it not work at all, like a disable method.
b) However... allowedButtonsFilter could be by default "button == primary || button == secondary || button == tertiary", and, relaxing further, situations like buttons = primary | secondary could be allowed. I just did this (5038e86) and reverted 😭. The second gesture will cancel the first (you'll never get primary and secondary click at the same time, at least with a mouse), so it will only ever work with a single gesture. I'll keep a).

Though I do worry a bit that not adding allowedButtonsFilter to some GestureRecognizers may lead to a inconsistent experience for a developer as they might expect DoubleTapGestureRecognizer to have allowedButtonsFilter like other GestureRecognizers do. @Piinks @a-wallen what are your thoughts on this?

Sure, I can make this (52c85b2). AllowedButtonsFilter would disable it, but if there is no callback, it also auto disables it. The logic behind LongPress is "if mouseButton matches callback, allow the pointer". You could have the callback and use allowedButtonsFilter to cancel it.
The default value doesn't matter because isPointerAllowed already prevents multiple buttons (see the default: return false). But yeah, a bit of redundancy won't hurt.

comments.author: antholeole
comments.bodyText:
This whole comment assumes that there's no way to drag the right handle without it already being in view. If that's a wrong assumption, then disregard :).
I wonder if this is the correct solution for this problem... The reason why this is not a problem for the second selection handle is that the call to selectionDelegate.bringIntoView in _handleSelectionHandleChanged always does nothing since dragging the second selection handle means the end of the selection extent is already in view. It gets called for both left and right handles, but never ever does anything for the right handle.
if we know that it shouldn't be called when dragging the left handle, and never does anything when dragging the right handle - do we need this call at all? Can't we just delete it and all is well?

If so, I think it would be best (i.e. smallest footprint) if this PR was just deleting that line, and the tests you wrote.

@justinmc @antholeole
I see. thank you.
yeah, I said I could remove selectionDelegate.bringIntoView in _handleSelectionHandleChanged only when there is my fix.
however, we can't remove other bringIntoView to pass tests. e.g. _editableText?.bringIntoView in _handleSelectionChanged.
it seems selectionDelegate.userUpdateTextEditingValue in _handleSelectionHandleChanged internally calls other bringIntoView also. (in short , as a result, _handleSelectionHandleChanged is calling bringIntoView two times now)
therefore, anyway I think we need some flag like isEnd to tell which handle is dragged now.

comments.author: vaind
comments.bodyText:
@jmagman extracting the dsymutil call to build_system/targets/ios.dart looked like a great idea and I've experimented with it here: https://github.com/vaind/flutter/commit/17d17ed5ae2887ddfca9a66daffd400c7bfeddd0
The problem is that the produced dSYM actually doesn't contain any debug information, because the AOT snapshot is already stripped by build.dart AOTSnapshotter. Seems like dsymutil will happily create the file even on a stripped binary...
We could have the logic to exclude strip in build.dart, as it is in this PR, while keeping the extraction in ios.dart target but that seems counterproductive to keeping things "closer".
Additionally, I've found an issue in this PR - it doesn't actually strip after creating the dSYM. This is especially an issue if obfuscate is enabled. Therefore, I will be updating it to strip manually just after creating the dSYM.
This approach is feeling a bit hacky and it really would be much nicer if we could get dSYM style dwarf out of dart's gen_snapshot directly, but I guess that's quite a stretch, right @mraleph @sstrickl?

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
The changes mentioned in #85118 (comment) did not help. I was able to get the collected shaders with this to work with a few modifications to the integration test:
Approach 1 - setting the frame policy, using timeouts
https://github.com/jiahaog/hello_flutter_integration_test/blob/2a423a4ea157cec90d395ab27ef7e0663977d283/integration_test/collect_sksl_test.dart#L9-L34
Approach 2 - Large time dilation value
https://github.com/jiahaog/hello_flutter_integration_test/blob/20d77e8842aa055345ef3a3151b8dda9ecb64469/integration_test/collect_sksl_test.dart#L8-L26
The value of timeDilation required for pumpAndSettle is fairly large. I suspect that using pumpAndSettle is potentially expensive, which relates to #84994 where frames are missed, preventing the shaders from being cached properly, so we need to set the time dilation to a large value.

I'm less favourable to the first approach since that requires the use of timeouts, and changing the frame policy may not be compatible with existing tests, which does not make them portable for both regular testing and collecting of SkSL.
@dnfield any thoughts about the above? For approach 2 we could potentially send a signal from the Tool to the test to increase the time dilation, though it may not be easy to choose a good value. Or is there a way to disable frame skipping entirely (as mentioned in #84994)? Then existing tests can be reused without code changes.
Workspace for reference: https://github.com/jiahaog/hello_flutter_integration_test/tree/cache-sksl

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: Yes, you may be able to find some success by playing around with the time dilation value.

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText:
I think this makes sense - if your test skips frames (perhaps because of shader compilation), it will likely not have shaders.
I agree that time dilation is probably the way to go. I think as long as it's set low enough it should just work right? It sounds like what we basically want is something where the framework gets to render every possible frame of every animation. Time dilation is more or less a timeout in this sense, since we're saying we'll slow things down and that should be enough for the rasterizer to finish its work on every frame. That should work in most cases, but it would be even better if we just had some kind of new frame policy like neverSkip or something.

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: I'm not sure if frame skipping happens within the framework or engine, would you have a pointer to the code that controls that?

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText: You'd have to do some tracing through the scheduler binding - I think if you look at the way the time dilation logic is handled, it may be possible to instead just adjust it so that it appears that we've always passed a single frame's worth of time (e.g. 16ms).

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: Thanks, I'll try that out 🙂

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
flutter test runs the tests in an 800x600 window with dpr=3x, which is extremely different from most phones. Could that be an issue?
(Should we close this PR? It hasn't been touched in a while.)

comments.author: dnfield
comments.bodyText:
integration_test overrides those settings to match the size/dpr of the host device.
I think we should close this. The guidance around using SkSL is about to change anyway.

title: Improve performance of Widget Tests
author: Jia Hao

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: @Hixie I'm not sure if this is a breaking change though (maybe this change should be a opt-in / opt-out?) - I patched this change and ran the global presubmit internally, and there is a test that broke (sent you an email linking the breakage). I'm not too familiar with creating custom render objects, but the breakage is coming from a custom render object that is doing some weird things for their intrinsic calculations. Let me know what you think!

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
I'm not sure if this is a breaking change

See https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Tree-hygiene#1-determine-if-your-change-is-a-breaking-change for how to determine what is considered a breaking change. Long story short though, if it breaks a test in google3 then yes, it's a breaking change.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
If this breaks something, that seems concerning, though...
cc @goderbauer

comments.author: jiahaog
Hixie
comments.bodyText:
That setup is probably already buggy. It's hard for me to pin down exactly where it'll fail. Subclassing RenderWrap is something I would discourage; composition is better than subclassing for changing layout behaviour. Render objects that talk to each other is bug-prone because their lifecycles aren't synchronised; for example, in the code above nothing seems to ensure that sizeOverride will trigger a layout when changed, so the API is subtle at best. Returning different values from computeMinIntrinsicWidth based on what is happening in performLayout will cause caching issues, as you've discovered.
It's hard for me to advise because I don't really know what this code is trying to do, but I suspect the answer is to entirely change the approach being taken here.

comments.author: jiahaog
jiahaog
comments.bodyText: Spoke to the original author of the internal breakage and resolved it by moving them away from the separate render object. @Hixie can you take a look again before I get started on the breaking change process?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
The point of not caching is that we want to make sure that the same result is returned every time. If we decide to not test that, then why not just use the regular cache, instead of having two caches?
I'm worried that caching is going to miss the exact types of bugs that led us to disable the cache in the first place though.

comments.author: jiahaog
Hixie
comments.bodyText:
I looked into this some more. Here's the problem in a nutshell:
If we don't call markNeedsLayout on the parent when we have cached intrinsic dimensions, then the parent's cache won't be invalidated, so it will start reporting incorrect results.
If we do call markNeedsLayout on the parent when we have cached intrinsic dimensions, then the parent will layout in debug mode (when checking intrinsics) but won't in release mode, leading to bugs being hidden in tests, the worst place to hide bugs.
In fact there's a bug in the PR right now, because we don't invalidate the cache of the parent when the child is marked dirty for layout and has cached debug intrinsic dimensions.
Basically there's no way to correctly implement caching for debug-only intrinsic dimension logic.
(We should add a test that checks this, even if we don't land this PR.)

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: Thanks for taking a closer look! I'll have to come back on this, but I sent #71539 anyway to add the tests you mentioned (which fails when this PR is patched). I'm quite new to layout though, so do let me know if the test covers the correct thing.

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
Would clearing the debug intrinsic cache of the parent separately help with this?
E.g. jiahaog@3279c0b (with this PR as the base commit), which will keep the the test added in #71539 passing.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: Consider the case where the parent isn't a RenderBox, but still does the debug intrinsics dance with its RenderBox children.

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
If I understand correctly, jiahaog/flutter@3279c0b wouldn't work because if the parent is not a RenderBox, clearing of the debug intrinsic cache will stop there and will not propagate to the grandparent which might be a RenderBox.
Just offering some ideas around this here – any thoughts about the following?

Having a protected method in RenderObject to propagate clearing of the debug intrinsics to parents, just like how markNeedsLayout does it to avoid the aforementioned problem
Having some sort of global variable for that consolidates debug intrinsic caches instead, such as Map<RenderBox, Map<_IntrinsicDimensionsCacheEntry, double>>, where keys are every RenderBox and values are the debug intrinsic cache for a particular RenderBox. So when markNeedsLayout is called, this global variable can be quickly cleared to remove all cached debug intrinsics

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Having a protected method in RenderObject to propagate clearing of the debug intrinsics to parents, just like how markNeedsLayout does it to avoid the aforementioned problem


RenderObject can't know about this, it's specific to RenderBox (and other subclasses that might support intrinsics). The whole point of having RenderObject and RenderBox be separate is to allow RenderObject to be ignorant about this kind of thing so people can make new rendering subclasses with different semantics. :-)
(Or to put it another way: Consider what you would do if RenderBox was not part of Flutter's framework, but was in a custom package. Would we accept a patch that modified RenderObject just to support this esoteric feature of that package?)


Having some sort of global variable for that consolidates debug intrinsic caches instead, such as Map<RenderBox, Map<_IntrinsicDimensionsCacheEntry, double>>, where keys are every RenderBox and values are the debug intrinsic cache for a particular RenderBox. So when markNeedsLayout is called, this global variable can be quickly cleared to remove all cached debug intrinsics


I suppose that could work... I'm really reluctant to introduce global variables though, one almost always regrets doing so. Also, would this actually improve performance? If we blow away the entire cache any time markNeedsLayout is called, there's not going to be much time that the cache actually does anything useful. It might even make things slower...

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
Thanks for explaining it to me! Yeah, it would make sense that the intrinsics are kept contained within the RenderBox implementation, it will not be appropriate to add a method to RenderObject just for this.

I suppose that could work... I'm really reluctant to introduce global variables though, one almost always regrets doing so. Also, would this actually improve performance? If we blow away the entire cache any time markNeedsLayout is called, there's not going to be much time that the cache actually does anything useful. It might even make things slower...

Do you think using the global variable would be worth it though? I can't quite think of any other way to reference all the RenderBox in the widget tree to clear the cache properly at this time... To quantify the performance improvements, I created an internal patch using a global variable as described for the debug intrinsic cache, and ran the slowest 35 test targets. Across these targets they complete on average ~30% faster, and the runtime improvements vary to up to 70% faster for certain targets. Happy to share the data internally as well.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
That's a big improvement, I'm surprised. I suppose it's just that we're avoiding the O(N^2) effect because each time we walk the entire tree for intrinsics, we cache the results at each stage the whole thing becomes O(N)? I guess that makes sense...
Thinking about this some more, what would happen in the case of a RenderBox->RenderFoo adapter? e.g. consider a RenderBox whose child is a RenderFoo where the Foo protocol has some sort of intrinsics equivalent. The Box would ask the Foo for its intrinsic size, the Foo asks its child, reports the answer back to the Foo, which gives it to the Box. If RenderObject.debugCheckingIntrinsics is true, though, the child might not set up a relationship with its parent, so when it later changes, it calls markNeedsLayout on itself, but it finds it doesn't need to call markNeedsLayout on its parent. The RenderBox never gets dirtied, so the cache isn't cleared. This seems like it would then start returning bad values...
Do you still get the improvement if we just clear the cache on every frame? The binding in the rendering library already knows about box.dart so it would be reasonable for it to go and clear out the cache (you'd have to have a public method for clearing the cache, I guess, but that's ok...).

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
what would happen in the case of a RenderBox->RenderFoo adapter?

Yeah... Unfortunately this edge case wouldn't work with the global cache then :(. I tried out your suggestion to clear the cache on every frame, by doing it at the end of drawFrame. This does still give the performace improvement, but it also causes some tests to fail internally with intrinsic check failures, probably because widgets might be marked dirty multiple times within a frame in between intrinsic checks.
Something else I tried was to clear the global cache instead before every RenderBoxs' intrinsic checks. This does not result in the failures, but the performace gains are not as significant - it averages to about 15% faster, down from 30% previously. This probably happens because there's still a bunch of wasted work recalculating intrinsics when the widgets are not dirty.
I think what we might want here is to somehow hook into all implementations of RenderObject and when they mark themselves as dirty, clear the global cache. There doesn't seem to be a simple way of doing this though. Even if we could add some sort of debugAssertDoesMeetConstraintsClearGlobalCache method to RenderObject API (not that it's the best idea) and place it in RenderObject.markNeedsLayout, implementations such as RenderFoo don't necessarily need to call super.markNeedsLayout, and there's doesn't seem to be a way of reliably knowing that RenderFoo is dirty.
This does seem a bit difficult to implement correctly and I can't think of anything else that might solve the edge case you pointed out at this time. I guess an option here would be to settle for the smaller performance gains, but I'd like to think a bit more about this over the weekend :)

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: We could also make this particular test easier to turn off for entire groups of tests. @tvolkert made a thing that lets you configure the tests once, he used it to make the golden tests work. Maybe we can use that to just turn off these tests for teams where the tests are too slow? (We'd have to document how to do this somewhere on our Web site if that's what we recommend.)

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
I spent some more time thinking about it, and here are some ideas :)
Option A: Add debugMarkDirtyForAssertDoesMeetConstraints to RenderObject, annotate markNeedsLayout with @mustCallSuper
Example: #72252
~30% faster on average for the slowest 35 internal targets.
We can introduce to RenderObject the concept of an accompanying cleanup method for debugAssertDoesMeetConstraints, named debugMarkDirtyForAssertDoesMeetConstraints. Descendants of RenderObject can implement it, and it will be called in RenderObject.markNeedsLayout. In this case, RenderBox will implement it to clear the global debug intrinsics cache.
To make sure that clients do not override this logic in RenderObject.markNeedsLayout, we can add the @mustCallSuper annotation to RenderObject.markNeedsLayout. This doesn't look like a breaking change (from running internal tests).
I'm a bit on the fence about this approach, because it feels a bit more difficult to explain to users how to implement it for non-RenderBox operations. Perhaps the method can be renamed to something like beforeMarkNeedsLayout as a generic callback for implementators of RenderObject to do work.
Option B: Add a global intrinsics cache, always clear it before intrinsic checks
Example: #72260
~15% faster on average for the slowest 35 internal targets.
We can also go with the smaller performance gains with the advantage of keeping the cache invalidation simpler. This will involve just wiping the entire intrinsics global cache right before the checks.
[Suggested] Option C: Make intrinsic checks lazy, relax checks
Example: #72258
~30% faster on average for the slowest 35 internal targets.
Previouly we discussed the need to use a separate cache for intrinsic checks, because we do not want to affect real layout. What if we instead simplified the intrisic checks so that we don't need a separate cache?
The eager intrinsic checks introduces additional caching keys due to the extra constraints of doing intrinsic computations with double.infinity, and constraints.min/max/height/width, which might never be encountered in the lifetime of the RenderBox. We could instead validate just the values that are already computed as part of real layout. The example PR above probably needs a bit more work and structure, but it shows this in more detail.
The gist of it is to make the checks lazy and use the real layout cache for the intrinsic checks. _computeIntrinsicDimension is augmented to do the intrinsics checks instead as and when values are returned. It checks if the returned values are not negative and finite, and attempts to check for min < max as and when the values are saved into the cache.
Option D: Figure out some way to make it easier to turn the checks off
Turning off the intrinsic size checks makes the tests ~35% faster on average for the slowest 35 internal targets.
(Assuming the prior art for configuring golden tests is #16859)
Currently it is possible to turn the intrinsic checks off by subclassing either of the TestWidgetsFlutterBindings, and overriding the getter checkIntrinsicSizes. Perhaps we can make this instance property a setter or even a top level library setter (like goldenFileComparator) which will make it easier for users to toggle.
This is more convenient but I feel like it might end up being buried somewhere in the documentation as a configuration though. Perhaps we can add some sort of heuristic to the tool or package:flutter_test, for when tests exceed a certain time to tell users of the existence of that configuration to make it more discoverable too.
Option E: Option D + any other option listed above
Option D of making the flag easier to configure is not exclusive with the other options listed, and a solution could be a combination of those options.

Personally I like option C better, but I'm not sure if relaxing the checks is alright as they might still offer some value. What do you think?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
The problem with C is that it doesn't catch the problems we want to catch. The real goal of these asserts, at the end of the day, are to verify that the render objects we write in the framework all implement all the right intrinsic logic. Admittedly they don't catch every problem, we still have some errors that fall through the cracks, but at least they catch a bunch of them. (We never see those failures because they get caught when someone tries to implement intrinsics and gets it wrong, before they land their PR.)
A sounds like it would make our developer experience worse so i'd steer away from that. B might work, but D might just be easier. We could even default the tests off and set the flag in the framework's configuration.

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText:
Got it! Sounds like we want to explore option D then.

We could even default the tests off and set the flag in the framework's configuration.

Can you elaborate a bit more about what you mean by the framework configuration here?

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText:
Can you elaborate a bit more about what you mean by the framework configuration here?

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter/test/flutter_test_config.dart and related files.

comments.author: tvolkert
comments.bodyText: See the package docs in https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/flutter_test/flutter_test-library.html

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: Yup, flutter_test_config.dart is not supported on web platforms. Sending #72488 separately to fix that.

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: #72488 has been merged, so updated the PR and the description. Please take a look again @Hixie :)

comments.author: jiahaog
comments.bodyText: Thanks for the review and all the help! I'll look into manually turning on these checks for internal tests that involve widgets with custom intrinsic overrides.

comments.author: Hixie
comments.bodyText: Thank you for sticking with it even through my faffing around and pedantry!

title: Add HtmlElementView (the Flutter Web platform view)
author: Harry Terkelsen

comments.author: amirh
comments.bodyText: Hi, it would help me if you could point me to the companion code that sizes / creates / presents webview on the web so I have more context when reviewing.

comments.author: hterkelsen
comments.bodyText:
The corresponding platform code is here: https://github.com/flutter/engine/blob/master/lib/stub_ui/lib/src/engine/platform_views.dart
And here is the surface which displays it in our DOM tree:
https://github.com/flutter/engine/blob/master/lib/stub_ui/lib/src/engine/surface/platform_view.dart
Only create is implemented on the platform side so far.

comments.author: amirh
comments.bodyText:
Is there a design doc available? Seems like we're going with an approach similar to AndroidView for sizing which is more complex than the UiKitView approach due to specific Android limitations.
We're working on migrating as much shared functionality from AndroidView and UiKitView to common classes (PlatformViewSurface and PlatformViewLink), see #36779 some of it landed already, I wonder if we can use that for the web as well.

comments.author: hterkelsen
comments.bodyText:
I don't have a design doc. Most of the code for HtmlView is copied from AndroidView but now that I'm looking over it again and I see that some of the things in the view controller remained that I meant to take out (ie acceptGesture and rejectGesture).
I'll write a doc for why I wasn't able to do gesture detection in the framework for HtmlView and also simplify the resizing code and update this PR tomorrow.

comments.author: hterkelsen
comments.bodyText: Updated the code. I'm writing a doc now explaining why web restricts HtmlViews from participating in Flutter gesture detection and explaining the HtmlView widget lifecycle. I'll update this PR when the doc is ready

comments.author: hterkelsen
comments.bodyText: @amirh I wrote a doc explaining HtmlView and why I was unable to do gesture detection for them. Take a look here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JxXrxzO2CJGcrDYvTGQqbJDW4S2chLp3vCrzPaZsGHI/edit?usp=sharing

comments.author: rostopira
comments.bodyText: Any ETA for this PR to merge? It's a blocker for me currently

comments.author: chertov
comments.bodyText: I'm waiting for release! It will awesome to get html5 video, Media Source API, webrtc.. etc

comments.author: hterkelsen
comments.bodyText: I just got back from vacation today. I'll update and try to land this PR by EOW
